text: The employees are great and work to help the guests.  It's a great place to chill and you can work out with weights in the upstairs area if you're all climbed out.I took a lesson with Jake and was blown away by his quality of instruction.  He carefully observes your technique and earnestly tells you your weaknesses and strengths.  He then offers critical advice on how to improve your conditioning and climbing skills.  If you want to improve at climbing, see Jake!!!

It's been a while since I first set foot in here. Back in the old days, I was taking a rock climbing class at Santa Monica College. The class met at this gym, Rockreation.This place not only has a good number of climbing wall of various difficulty levels, but also has some the the same equipment you'd see in a standard gym. To climb, a partner is needed to hold the rope while you make your way to the top. I don't climb often, but when I come here, it is a fun experience. Of course, climbing in this gym and climbing real rock formations are very different experiences. This is a good place to get your foundation.The staff here is cool, and the experience has been fun ever since I first came here. If climbing is your thing, or if you want to get started in this fun pastime, then give this place a try.

I'm sure the gym is great, but I had a nightmare experience with the person at the counter. Wasted a half hour getting the song and dance from her about the belay system to find out my daughter couldn't climb.  And on top of it the gym isn't set up with any auto belay so I wouldn't be able to climb anyway. The whole experience was lame, and they way I was talked to made me feel like you had to be a seasoned pro to use their facility. I'd avoid this place if you don't want to be frustrated with an unhelpful staff.

Pretty cool location!Went there for one of my son's friends birthday parties.  The good place was pretty clean and organized.  There is the scent of "stinky feet", but hey, it's a physical activity place.  There were different walls for varying degrees of difficulties.  Some walls had the auto valet which catches people if the fall or go down.  Others need to have someone hold the rope.The staff were pretty attentive and took care of all the kids that were there.  They were really focused on safety which was reassuring as a parent.The event room was a good size and had tables and chairs probably good for 30 comfortably.All in all, good experience and makes me want to try it out for myself one of these days.

I had a fantastic experience! My daughter threw her 8th birthday party there and everything went smooth. It was her best birthday. I only gave it 4.8 stars because we had little help except for making sure the payment due was paid. They helped with assisting in the climbing for all the kids and putting on the harnesses. We had about 17 kids, and 10 adults. The party room was a great size and clean. I'll post pictures, but it was a great party. 2 hours was more than enough time. Parking is limited to 11 spots and most are taken when you get there. There is street metered parking.
Only downfalls are they dont open until around noon and the bouldering area is small compared to other gyms.  Great staff, community, and weight area.  Everything I need.

Great indoor climbing gym. There are only three auto belays but plenty of space for bouldering and a great variety of routes for different climbing capabilities. They offer classes and usually have great deals offered on Groupon if you're checking it out for the first time. I'm also pretty sure that you're first pass might be on the house, and if you're a member you can take one guest for free each month. Super friendly staff. Street parking only - parking lot is not for guests.

I've been here 3x.  Twice about 10-15 years ago to climb with friends and once a week or two ago to take a 2 hour class, which went for about 2.5 hours.  I love indoor rock climbing, but did not come here for a long time because as soon as you walked in, it smelled like feet.  Upon returning, I didn't really notice that problem.  Maybe it slightly smelled of sweat?  The class was about safety - tying knots, spotting, the gear, verbal commands, etc.  I never had to learn all of that except the verbal commands since I would go with friends.  My only job was to climb since it was my first time.  They are so nice.  LOL So I was like UGH I have to listen and pay attention in class on the weekend?!  So I did fairly well in paying attention and it wasn't too bad.  However, I pretty much forget everything after I left.  I did enjoy climbing.  I can't speak to price since my friend gave me a Groupon.  The staff was very friendly and nice though.  They also have a small gym upstairs and offer yoga classes etc as part of the membership. There is always a ton of parking.

For two years in a row, we've had a group of students come to Rockreation for a couple hours of climbing. The students come from a few different schools and while some are eager to climb, others have much more apprehension. The team that recently hosted our event was fantastic. They met each climber's needs, kept them safe, and challenged them appropriately to get the most out of the event. At the end, they played a fun game that engaged them all and was the perfect ending to a great evening. Thank you for your combined effort, diligence, and patience in making this a worthwhile experience for all involved.

It's been a while since I last was here. I first came here as part of a SMC class for a semester and it was a fabulous experience. Big place with lots of walls. The staff here are wonderful and eager to help you get off your feet.

My 6 year-old had a great time, he was very comfortable after his 2-hr session which is not bad for a first-time climber. The staff was very helpful and patient with him. I wish they had a gym just like this in the valley. Highly recommend!

Walk in was about $18 for day pass. You can rent out gear if you want. This place has pretty good routes. They don't have a lot of automatic belays so you may have to wait awhile to be able to use one. I came in on a Sunday at around 4 pm. There were a lot of kids which is great to see that they're into the sport but also you may have to wait for the automatic belays.Their bouldering area isn't as great as other places I've been. The routes aren't as extensive so after you've done a few, it gets kinda boring. They are making the most of the space they have which is understandable.They do have a gym which is pretty nice. I didn't get to see what kind of equipment they have. The bathrooms were clean.I would come back here again if I were in the area.

Five stars is not enough for the amazing instructors and other staff members at Rockreation. I have been coming here twice a week for adult climb time lessons for almost two months. I went from never setting foot in a rock climbing gym or anything climbing related and being scared of heights to being very comfortable climbing.I HIGHLY recommend adult climb time classes. It's very reasonably priced and the instructors are all so nice and helpful. It's also basically a private lesson.I will continue to come here with joy!

Rockreation rocks! I recently worked with the team at Rockreation LA to organize a fundraising event for a climbing organization that I volunteer with. Everything went very smoothly and all of the staff members were extremely friendly and easy to work with. I only have good things to say about booking them for a private event. The gym offers a variety of classes for both new and experienced climbers. They have plenty of climbing routes along with bouldering, self-belaying, and both cardio and weight lifting equipment. They even have a small studio for yoga and exercise classes! Rockreation feels like a really community, and I imagine that people who climb here regularly climb together outside of the gym as well. I would definitely consider signing up for a membership here in the future. It's so close to UCLA and I like that they have exercise equipment and classes in addition to climbing. I can't wait to come back soon!

We had a birthday party for my son here yesterday and it could not have gone better. The staff were attentive to the kids, checked in with me, communicated, took the lead on making sure they followed the rules, kept them entertained, were encouraging and the kids had a BLAST!  The room for the party is private and separate and located right next to the entrance. It's bare so you bring in whatever you need. We booked the room for an extra half hour, at the end, to feed the kids and sing happy birthday and it was perfect.  The staff was courteous, considerate, and worth every (expensive) penny we paid for the party. Although you are for sure paying more than a party somewhere else that includes food, gift bags etc I still felt it catered to my son's personal enjoyment and was way safer than a trampoline park.   Thanks for a great party!

This is the friendliest and most welcoming rock climbing gym in the US!  The staff is always super kind and willing to help out.  It's a wonderful gym for the first time climber and advanced climber alike! My favorite part about this gym is the genuinely welcoming community that they build.  Their manager Jenn Tanaka is such an honest, welcoming, empowering leader and her sincerity shines through all the staff, instructors, coaches, parties, and community events they hold.  I've been climbing here for two years now and have met some of my best friends in LA here.  The team here knows how keep everyone safe, motivate you to get better AND have the most fun.  I highly recommend taking personal coaching classes as the one-on-one instruction is the best, most supportive, and friendliest you're going to find.  The class instructors are super, and the yoga and rockfit classes are phenomenal.  Definitely a great spot for the whole family, they have kids birthday parties and the staff know how to make those parties AWESOME , I've even seen them get the parents in on the fun too.  I've seen their teambuilding courses and kids birthday parties change peoples attitudes from fear and self doubt to empowered tears of joy and happiness as they conquer their fears.  This staff knows how to make conquering your fears fun and safe.If you are looking to try out climbing for the first time just go in and say Hey friends! I have no idea what I'm doing but this looks fun! will you show me the ropes? and they will take it from there introducing you to the best sport/meditation around :) (Granted you or a guardian fill out a waiver for you, everyone needs a waiver )I cannot recommend a gym more highly.  There is no sort of "snobbery" or anything of that sort.  I know all of their staff personally and If anyone corrects you its only because they are trying to protect you, and they take your safety seriously.  So swallow your ego, listen to the rules and enjoy learning an awesome new skill.  Everyone wants you to be the best climber you can be, and the best climber- is the one who's having the most fun! P.S. GET TO KNOW THE STAFF, THEY ARE RAD!!!!

Rockreation is amazing! I've been coming steadily for the past 5 months and I can't say enough wonderful things about this gym. The staff is beyond friendly, knowledgeable, and eager to show you the ropes (ha get it). Anyway, overall there is such a welcoming community all throughout. P.S. it's open for Memorial Day. Special shout out to Lucy at the front desk.
This was an awesome rock climbing gym.  Friendly staff and lots of variety in the climbs.

This place is awesome. Clean, nice locker room and restroom. The staff is really friendly and knowledgeable. They also change the courses frequently, so it's always challenging. We do private lessons with Ben, and he's an amazing coach.
My son took a rock climbing class here.  The staff and facility is amazing.  Love it!

I've been spoiled with the gym close to my house so this one is just average.  It's a smaller gym with a small parking lot, although there is street parking.  The routes are short and closer together than what I'm used to.  There are fewer options and the ratings are true to the difficulty level. We came on a Friday evening, and the gym was not at all crowded.  I'd say half of the climbers were kids under 18 that day.Although the routes being short is a con, there is an advantage to that as well.  Some of the routes have overhangs and I'm not a strong overhang climber.  With the routes being short here, it's easier for me to make the climb because once I get over that part, I'm almost done with the route.  Whereas, with my regular climbing gym, once I'm past the overhang, I still have half the route to go, which wears me out.  There is also at least one self belaying station for those of you who don't have a climbing partner. Climbs using that machine vary ranging from the low 5s to at least a 5.10, so it's good for all levels.  I've yet to try that out as I'm not too keen on the feeling I get from being lowered on one.  They also have routes set up for lead climbs, but you'll have to bring your own rope, which we didn't do. Of course, before you do any kind of belaying, you'll have to pass their belay test.  Once you pass that, you're in their system and you're good to go next time you're here.  Also, there are lockers in the bathrooms, but not locks, so you'll have to provide your own as well.  Overall, I'd come back to this gym, but I wouldn't go out of my way to make it here as I have a gym much closer to home.

Just signed up at Rockreation. They have an great Black Friday deal where you save $100 on the initiation fee. With unlimited family memberships of $150 per month, including yoga, meditation and cardio classes plus use of gym equipment it really doesn't get any better!Rockreation is very well maintained and conveniently located. And the staff is friendly and helpful.I'm so excited to master this new sport!

After reading the reviews, I was excited to meet the famous stinky staff person, but alas, so far I've only met clean, friendly staff people who seem happy to help me rethink (bouldering) problems. Also I love the music- sometimes"indie chill", sometimes hip hop, but thankfully never classic rock. It's a smaller gym in an office park, so the routes are squished together, which can be visually confusing, but your brain will figure it out. Cardio machines are older, but functional. Hours vary based on the day, check the schedule before you go. Limited parking lot spaces.

i don't like writing a negative review, but sometime service is so awful and individuals demonstrate pride in the level of rudeness and disrespect they can project. CHRISTIAN (played by the Pharmacy-Bro) at the front desk of of the West LA location took great pride in turning me and my girlfriend away on her birthday. he did not want to honor the groupon we purchased despite very clear terms on it and once he felt a little empowered over us, would not even honor the pricing on the menu on his desk. all this mid-week AM and not at all busy. CHRISTIAN was clearly being aggressive for no good reason and even though cost was not at all the issue for us (we just wanted a proper explanation), sometimes you reach a point were you just don't want to give such ugly people your money.in the scope of things it was so unimportant, but the more we thought about how aggressive and mean CHRISTIAN was we felt we needed to provide some sort of record or warning. particularly as Jacob the manager albeit a good listener and polite and clearly embarrassed by CHRISTIAN's conduct was unwilling or unable to address the situation. when we looked up the yelp and saw so many bad reviews to this location many of which reference the same CHRISTIAN and others at the front desk being rude and disparaging to others, it really shocked us and made us very sad. it is amazing Rockreation allows it and has not addressed such a clear issue on their yelp. allowing someone to go on with such conduct is truly awful. As they say evil is when good people say nothing in the face of bad behavior.we hope this lovely facility gets better people and clearer leadership on service and kindness. we certainly were looking forward to some fun climbing. BE WARNED as there are so many good and decent merchants that better deserve your patronage and will offer you at the least kindness, honesty and respect.

This gym has everything you need. Bouldering, top roping, lead climbing on a 1 of a kind arch, and a work out area upstairs. Definitely a good way to spend your time. I climb regularly and Rockreation has all I need to stay in shape for outdoor climbing. Also I enjoy the staff. They're always down to chat about climbing even if you've just met. Joe and Christian have always been cool, and maybe if you're lucky you'll get to catch one of Guy's fitness classes.  Thanks Rock for the good times!

Had a really good time taking the FG1 class recently.  Great instructors & fun experience!  I had bought a groupon for a friend for her birthday many many months ago.  Because of our schedules, we had to reschedule our class numerous times.  Every time I called, the employee on the other end, (mostly Jake), was super nice & very understanding & accommodating.  Even after the groupon had expired, they still let us change the date yet again due to schedule conflicts.   It was well worth it!

I've never felt more unwelcome at a gym, or a business for that manner. We tried this place out to find out that their staff are completely unwelcoming and actually got irritated when I asked for basic directions around the gym. I even asked for something simple like a different shoe size  and the "instructor" (who looks like he hasn't showered in months) was making rude comments to his staff about us. Sorry that I haven't been here and didn't know my way around? Honestly do you have half a brain? I'm a customer and you make us feel that way? I have an idea. How about you take a shower (or 10), and come to Open mat? I'm sure your attitude and body odor will be a revelation.
Perfect membership for the whole family. Kids love to climb, mom does yoga, and dad goes to the gym... unbeatable prices !

I had such a great experience at Rockreation last night in their FG1 class, and was so excited to learn to belay, something I was very nervous about before taking the class. Jake and Peter were fantastic instructors - fun, engaging, and highly effective at teaching. My friend and I had a great time!

I give this place a solid 4. My friend and I are not experienced climbers but wanted to try something different on a recent, hot, Saturday. We picked Rockreation because in addition to bouldering, they offered some auto-belay courses. When we arrived, the dude checking us in was very friendly and helpful. We had a blast on the auto-belay courses but definitely wish there were some more options. Next time, I definitely want to learn belay with my friend so we can try out all of the other courses. The bouldering section is awesome, but be aware, it's no joke. This isn't an "easy" activity but it was super fun. Your day pass gives you access to the entire gym, which is great for a different workout. I will certainly be back sometime soon and will update this review.

Great 6th birthday party for Jayla at Rockreation! Exactly what I wanted, only wish we could have 3 hrs instead of 2.Jenn, Jenny and Pablo were fab. They were knowledgeable, patient and encouraging to all the kids and adults who wanted to climb. 2 kids in particular were very scared but by the end of the party, with the help of the staff, they were climbing too and enjoying  themselves. The place was packed but our party ran smoothly.I would highly recommend this for any age. We will be going back.

I've been climbing on and off since 2005 and I really like this place. Great route setting and welcoming, chill vibe. I meet so many awesome people here. Plus Von offers a cardio hip hop class that is SO MUCH FUN. See, it's not aerobics and it's not like a performance class or anything. You follow his moves and everyone has a blast.The Rockreation description says it like this (and it's super accurate) ..."No rhythm? No problem! Von's hip-hop class makes it easy for anyone to jump in and get moving to a mix of old school hip-hop and pop jams. Class will include dropping it like it's hot, shaking it like a Polaroid picture, and dippin' like dots! Whoa!"

At one point I wanted to just buy a gym membership here since it was so conveniently located. They have a small gym upstairs with a bunch of fitness class offerings.  However, they told me they no longer do that, you must buy a climbing membership as well. They have a lot of great deals and partner with various companies month-to-month, so be on the lookout if you want to sign up as a member.Other than that, I've climbed here on occasion with friends, and taken their Flight Gravity Series class once, which I thought was good.  Not the biggest rock climbing gym, largest bouldering area, or highest top ropes in town, but good enough for me.  You do have to take a belay test before you can belay your friends.I've found that parking isn't too bad in this area.Overall, this place is great.
Had a very good experience. Spent about three hours there climbing with friends. Eric helped us out and was very pleasant. Would recommend.

Walls aren't very high, and the place isn't very big. Top rope walls arent labeled, but instead have a chart where you vote for what it should be labeled. bouldering routes were all labeled, and the ones are labeled would be labeled "v3/V4" not just one or the other. Staff was nice for the most part, one staff member belayed for me when he was off. But another staff member was clearly annoyed with me when I asked for a belay check and quite rude throughout the check.

My son has been learning to climb here with experienced and knowledgeable instructors for several years now.  He really loves it and has really progressed in his abilities. The gym is clean and well laid out and offers an incredible variety of courses and classes for people of all ages.  The staff is very helpful, warm and friendly. I would recommend Rockreation to anyone wanting to have fun while working out or learning a new sport!

Rockreation is awesome! My friend and I have taken two classes there and have been stunned both times by both the facility itself and the people that work there! There are enough walls and paths there that beginners and pros alike will love this place. It even features bouldering, which I though was a nice touch for  people who want a little different rock climbing challenge.But by far the most amazing thing about Rockreation are the employees there! Everyone there is so kind and considerate, from the front desk to instructors. With them, Rockreation a thousand times better! I cannot recommend this place enough to anyone!

Great place been a few times now. Really friendly staff ask them a question they offer loads of advice. I'm new to climbing so took the group lessons with a mate. Very good lessons, relaxed and fun and now me x my mate are climbing on our own in less than a week. Also hoping it wouldn't be one of those places where if you're not an expert you're in people's way. It's not got that feel at all. There's clearly good climbers doing crazy things I can't but fun to watch them.  If you're interested at all I can't say enough good stuff so just go try it.

The worst climbing gym in LA hands down!! Also , the dude at the front desk with the glasses , thanks for being an super unpleasant, unprofessional, unhelpful, micro-aggressive racist jerk. I won't be back to this stinky gym ever again.

I took the Fight Gravity series. Super helpful for my noobie self, and basically started my most recent obsession with rock climbing. I learned to belay and some general climbing techniques from class, but am finding it all comes with more practice. The staff here is wayyyyy cool and the community is also friendly. My only issue is the equipment is a bit old but I hear there are renovations coming shortly.

I've been going to Rockreation intermittently for years. . .so sad that it's taken me this long to write a review. You would never imagine that there is a climbing gym in this neighborhood. It's nice that they are right here in WLA. The location is convenient for westsiders, I work in the area.  They have gone through some major renovations over the past couple years, which includes a new higher and bigger boulder, new bathrooms and added an amazing workout area on the second floor. A definite plus to the gym. Their staff is always so friendly and warm. I enjoy the community feel. The climbing routes are always fun and challenging, I never get bored. I'd highly recommend it and can't wait for my kids to start climbing!

We did a birthday party for a 9 year old at Rockreation yesterday. The staff was friendly, helpful, patient and fun. We had a big room for presents, pizza and cake, and the kids were really excited to get back on the wall after their break - even though the party was over!  There are lots of different levels so if you are a serious climber you can have fun, and same for novices trying to get over their fear of heights. It's a great place to hang out, and we're looking forward to going back just for us to climb.

I booked a corporate event at RockReation and had a great experience from start to finish! Our instructors were friendly, knowledgeable, and very encouraging. The session started off with some group team building activities which got us working together and using our collective skills to solve problems and figure out challenges. After that, we broke off into teams and began climbing. It was a great day and wonderful way to develop our communication and teamwork skills. Major kudos to our instructors Brynne and Jason who were AMAZING!!!! Special thanks to Lee for being so flexible with the last minute booking!!! :)

Majority of staff is very friendly. Kids friendly. Lots of enthusiastic rock climbers. A bit cramped for the space, esp during the weekend. The only issue / one-off scenario I had was with one of the employees who was administering a beginner class. They focused and emphasized safety training, which was great. But because I was still getting used to the ropes (as I was just a beginner), I ended up with pinched cut from the ropes/buckle. The first thing that happened was the instructor got annoyed at me for getting injured and then proceeded to gather everyone in the class to point and tell them: "Class! See this is what happens when you don't follow instructions!" It really turned me off and I was pretty annoyed bc I was already injured (not like I purposely tried to injure myself - I tried to follow instructions as best as possible). Not saying they didn't emphasize safety training, just the instructor's attitude. They didn't have a safety kit either, just bandaids. I might give it another go but there are different rock climbing facilities in LA that i'd rather check out before coming back here again.

The perfect place to start your fitness routine that will keep you coming back! Whether you are new to the area or have lived in LA your whole life, you are pretty much guaranteed to build a community of motivated individuals to spend your time with, either through the amazing staff or the multitude of athletes that roam this gym. Rockreation is not only a climbing gym, but offers meditation, yoga, martial arts, dance, raw body movement, and personal training classes. And after your done with all of that, inquire about a massage, because they offer those too!! Your one stop fitness destination and the best place to meet people that love the active and outdoor life as much as you do!!

1st thing i want to say is that this rating could much easily get better, and I will edit my review if they ever fix their big issues.I've been to numerous rock climbing gyms. and this is my third membership. I am a member here solely due to the fact that they meet the basics for a rock climbing gym. they have bouldering and some sort of ballet.1st big issue they're size... much  much smaller than most the gyms within 30 miles  of the area. To their defense, santa monica is very expensive and they do a lot with the room they have but none the less it's small and very expensive.2nd issue their buddy system. Every other gym i've been to lets you bring one buddy per month for free with a membership. this place lets you bring one person for free, but it must be their first time. From a business standpoint, I don't understand this, most people do not join a gym after there first time. it usually takes a few times so why not let them bring the same friend two months in a row. Thats how i decided to sign up and I've had two friends get memberships at another gym i went to after bringing them a few times.3rd HUGE issue is the belay system. Both the gyms i've been to only had auto belay and I've never used a buddy belay system. So coming here they make you past a test and give you a prep piece of paper that looks like its from the 90s. They would not even let me use my phone to watch a youtube video on how to do it "for insurance issues." But they did suggest i purchase a $45 class that would show me how to tie a rope and how to brake a buddy. $45 after i just signed up for a membership for something that was learned off of youtube in less than 8 min.Basically if you're equally as far from this place as the other gyms, go to the other ones, much better quality gyms and cheaper. If you're like me and this is the closest BASIC gym, it will do but that's about it..

As a preface, this review is only applicable to the bouldering section. I did not utilize the toproping/leading section of the gym. Also, I've been a member of a couple of different gyms (all while in Northern CA) and wanted to give this gym a try to see if I could make it my home gym as it's on the way between my work and apartment.Unfortunately, despite the amazing location, I don't see myself coming to this gym on a regular basis. Parking is actually not as bad as some folks make it sound, I was able to find parking within a block of the place and, since I was coming in to work out, walking a block was not an issue. The front desk staff was extremely welcoming and friendly during my experience and they did a great job showing off the gym. The bathroom/locker rooms are all new and spotless.The bouldering area is tiny. It wasn't over populated the day that I went but I can see how it could get cramped easily. The routes aren't that great either. Actually, that's the main reason why I'm giving this place such a low rating. Not to say I'm that great of a climber but I do have experience climbing both indoor and outdoor and I found these routes really confusing and disconnected. Part of it is the fact that they'll have same colored routes intersecting or adjacent and the other part is that the routes themselves have no continuity. Also, a good section of the wall was just unlabeled. Not the biggest issue for me but I noticed it steered a good majority of the crowd to one section, making it even more crowded. Overall, great location, chill staff, decent space for a smaller gym but really underwhelming and disappointing in terms of routes. Sad to say, although this place would have been the most convenient for me in terms of driving, I don't see myself coming back here.

I was something like a first-timer since it has been years since I rock climbed/bouldered (and only once), but I received so much assistance and support that I was scaling the walls in no time. The lovely and amazing staff member Brynne showed me the ropes (no pun intended) offering great instruction full of warmth and encouragement. I had a blast; it was the rigorous fun I needed. I will be back!

My husband and I tried Rockreation from a groupon that we received. It was really fun to learn the ropes / climb techniques with my spouse. It was actually like a lesson on communication and trust! :)My husband wasn't a huge fan since the walls are only so high and he is already 6'6" himself, but I had a great time. I think we may try to climb in nature where he has more room to keep climbing. Awesome staff. Beautiful women's bathroom. Slightly stinky atmosphere - but it's a gym right?!

This place is great! I was a bit intimidated to start climbing again after a 10 year break so I decided to take some private lessons as a refresher course with my boyfriend. Our instructor, Steve, was amazing! He was enthusiastic, encouraging, knowledgeable and flexible with our moods and schedule. We couldn't have had a better re-introduction to climbing. Steve tailored classes to our skill level and preferences and checked in with us multiple times a week. He was really engaged in our progress and it helped keep us focused. We have gone back on our own and have found the rest of the staff and instructors to be helpful and accommodating as well. Seems like there's a lot of regulars but don't be nervous to try it out if your new. If you have no idea what you are doing or want to tighten up your workout routine take a lesson with Steve.

I used to come here religiously a few years ago. Although not a fan of the distinct foot funk, I loved it here! I'm serious, if you're easily put off by strong odors, don't come here, it reeks of feet, sweaty feet. Anyway, I love Rockreation, especially the boulder area. In my opinion they set some of the best routes. I've been to a few climbing gyms across the U.S. and this gym by far has routes that are pretty outstanding, not to mention challenging and for the most part rated correctly. On occasion, there were a couple routes that made me sit back and scratch my head in puzzlement but eventually if there was a will there was a way. My god, countless hours staring at the different colored routes - hating and loving them at the same time. I used to break a sweat on the pink routes but after putting in time over the course of many months I made it all the way to greens and blues!The top ropes here are decent too, but I recall liking the top ropes at Boulderdash in Thousand Oaks slightly better. Anyway, I took the Fight Gravity series and the instructors are great! They even have kid classes for the little ones.They also have a small area for weights and cardio. Last I was here they also offered up yoga classes a couple times during the week.The crowd here comprises of both newbies and regular climbers. Everyone is friendly and willing to give you a tip if you look like you need it. These folks will spot you and even cheer you on especially if you're trying to do a climb and look like you're almost at the top but your darn Elvis leg is shaking a million miles a second and your forearms are about to burst! You definitely feel the camaraderie here - it really is something to step back to admire and appreciate.Anyway, I made a lot of friends at this gym - some of which I still keep in touch with. It's a great place to go and challenge yourself, blow off some steam, make a new friend, and oh yeah, get in shape. I hope to be a regular again.

Honestly, this place was really disappointing if you don't know what your getting yourself into. We initially came in and were greeted very warmly. For three people it came to almost 80 dollars including everything (harness, chalk, shoes) but they didn't tell us that we would need to take paid classes and pass a profiency class to do 95% of the bouldering, now thats some bullshit and I go bouldering all the time in OC and have never had to deal with this. Anyways, Christina helped accomodate us and she was very nice about everything. I really was thankful that she was there.

Just finished a week of the Reach summer camp. We've been going the past 3 years, and my kid would not let us go this summer without signing up! I admittedly did try to not sign up this year, to save a little $$$ ... but of course, he remembered, and he reminded me. He loves this camp. That makes me happy. 5 stars.

I've been climbing here for almost a year and I love it. The gym isn't the largest, but the density of technical routes is impressive. The ratings are a little tougher here too. If I can do a certain level climb at Rockreation then I know I can easily do that same level anywhere else.

Let me start this off by saying that I am a fairly new climber. From the second I walked in the staff were extremely friendly and helpful. They showed me the ropes (literally) right off the bat. If you're a new climber looking to get into the sport, this place is for you. I can't explain enough how warm and friendly the staff are, they were so happy to answer all of my stupid questions and making sure I was always safe and still having a good time. I had so much fun that I can't see myself going to another gym. What a cool place!

My husband and I got a groupon for the Fight Gravity 1 class which comes with a week long membership. Drew and Dan taught the class and they were very friendly and helpful. After the class, you have to come back to take a test before you can climb and belay on your own. We're looking forward to going back this next week.Looking at the rates, I'm not sure if we would sign up for membership, but maybe we will reevaluate after the week!

Note: This review is for customer service only, not the climbing setup or gym.I bought a month long membership for $100, and after climbing decided it wasn't for me. I was expecting to pay the day rate + rentals. Nope, they refunded my $100 and didn't have me pay a dime. Wasn't expecting that. Very thoughtful and appreciated.

My girlfriend and I just took the Fight Gravity 1 class purchased on groupon. Great experience! Customer service was great! The instructors were very knowledgeable and made the class entertaining. I can't speak so much as far as other detailed things that a climber with years of experience would critique. Coming from a complete rock climbing newbie I highly recommend this place to anyone interested.

Maybe I'm just bitter because I couldn't send more than 50% of my climbs at Rockreation, but I certainly wasn't out to write a bad review from a climbing gym.As the only climbing gym in West LA (for now), I had to check it out.  Pros:- Cool staff.  Their payment system was glitching up and they were fine letting us through to pay later- Auto belays - yay!-  Short walls...for lead climbing.  If you're beginning lead climbing and afraid of the drop, I guess this would be the perfect gym for you?Cons:- At 10,000 sq ft of climbing, this gym is on the smaller side.- The top rope/lead walls are SHORT - no endurance climbs in here.- Whoever set the routes for bouldering problems, has an odd technique.  The start holds were literally a foot off the ground...I can do climbs with a sitting start, but this did not make sense.  Ain't nobody got time for that.- Unmarked routes.  On the bouldering wall, there were tons of routes that either discontinued halfway or were all-together unmarked.  Free form climbing, anyone? - The Sawtelle area is not the best for parking availability.After about 1.5 hrs of climbing, my friend and I left bored and frustrated at our lack of progress.  Suffice to say, I'll be waiting on the next new gym to pop up in West LA when I visit.

Rockcreation is not a good climbing gym. Been climbing on and off for the past 4 years and been to many different gyms.There were no more than 15-20 top-rope routes. Few of them were graded in the 5.8, 5.9 range. Just lower 5.5 - 5.7 then jumps up to 5.10a and on.There were way more lead routes, but when I went there was literally no one doing lead climbs. The lead and top-rope climbs were separated. Why not mix them in, so the crowded top-rope routes are spaced out along with the empty lead routes?Also, the different climbs aren't marked with tape, but have holds that are supposed to be the same color. Ends up being very confusing.I'd recommend Stronghold or one of the Touchstone gyms (LA Boulder, I think).

Rockreation is where my boyfriend taught me how to climb, so I obviously feel sentimental about it.... which is why I am giving it three stars. I've only been climbing for about 6 months and try to go at least twice a week, so my review is given through the eyes of a newbie trying to transform into a legit climber.Few quick notes: 1. I know my review below may sound critical, but I think due to the fact that climbing CAN be a very dangerous activity, it's ESPECIALLY pertinent to be proactive about everyone's safety.2. Climbers I've met here are some of the most supportive and friendly people I've met. It will probably be really easy for a newbie to come in and make friends/climbing partners.3. Staff members are generally friendly - ask them questions if you aren't sure about something.4. All the roped routes seem very bouldery... but that's probably to make up for the short wall. Other gyms with tall walls I've been to have settings that are mellow until you get to the 4th/5th clip (safe to fall at that point).5. Dirty carpet and feet smell? That seems unavoidable at any climbing gym. I just try to wipe my feet before leaving and have a separate pair of flip flops for my gym days. #1 annoying + dangerous thing about this gym:- Rockreation has kids' classes couple days out of the week... which coincide with the time when people are getting out of work and start coming into the gym (hectic!). As a fee paying customer, I don't like how climbers have to wait around for the kids' warm-ups and give up the main space so they can conduct their class. I don't remember agreeing to this inconvenience when I signed up. It's a SMALL space to begin with, and it's really awful because a lot of the kids don't know how to behave in a climbing gym. - I've had TOO MANY instances where kids (early teens - are they still kids?) bumped into me while I was belaying or they would trip over my rope. I even actually had a kid throw a shoe and hit me while I was belaying my partner as he was climbing the arch. What makes me angry is that some of the staff seem so lackadaisical about this type of unruliness. UNACCEPTABLE. I understand that they are kids, but they are under the gym's supervision... SO SUPERVISE THEM! Just a quick note to parents who bring in their young children into the gym: PLEASE DON'T LET THEM RUN AROUND WHILE YOU ARE CLIMBING. It is DANGEROUS. Supervised or not, they shouldn't be roaming around the gym where they can be a danger to climbers. I've actually seen a toddler in a diaper roam around willy nilly as the parents were climbing... and the kid ran into the belayer's arms...  O_O ... and the staff didn't say anything to them. GENERAL/UNIVERSAL note for everyone (important points + etiquette I've learned/observed): - DON'T step on someone else's rope. Especially when it's being used!- DON'T traverse or climb underneath a climber (for rope/boulder/auto belay!)- DON'T traverse too high (I actually recently saw a guy who fell off from almost at the top of the wall and smacked his head and got carried out by EMT). Even if you are a great climber, you never know if you'll slip off. Be considerate of the people you may hit if you fall. - DON'T wear your harness in the bouldering area. Do you really want to take the chance of falling weirdly on your harness/gear/carabiner?- LISTEN UP for people announcing "LOWERING" - you may have a climber being lowered over your head. Actually, don't stand around at points where climbers are going to be lowered, period. Always be aware of your surroundings!! - DON'T give a ton of unnecessary slack during lead climbing even if you're belaying a human monkey. I'm no expert, but if someone falls on their 2nd or 3rd clip and there's a ton of slack out.... you get my point (hopefully).

Over the past 8 years I've been a member of 3 different climbing gyms. Rockreation is the closest option (in regards to proximity) for me now.I have a flexible work schedule so I try to climb during the day - whenever I go at night it tends to be very crowded.I don't have any major gripes with Rockreation. Most of the staff are friendly. They recently redesigned the bouldering area and it's an improvement over the old setup.I really wish that they'd come up with a better guest pass system. I'd love to bring my girlfriend/visiting friends in to climb with me on occasion, but the current setup makes that pretty difficult. An expanded weight area would be nice too.

I have to give this place a four star just because it was my first ever experience with bouldering indoors.  If it wasn't my first experience, I would given this place a three just because there's not much space to boulder.My friends and I went on a Friday night and supposedly it's considered a slower night than usual.  With that being said, the amount of people on a Friday was a lot in my eyes.  Everyone basically had to share the wall and wait for their turn.The staff were cool and trustworthy as well.  They were also helpful and knowledgable.

This place rocks!! (pun intended)Staff: Everyone is pretty friendly and willing to help . . . even when I had to go back and forth for a new pair of climbing shoes twice because they were either too tight or too loose. They even were really patient with me during my belaying test - I had some performance anxiety and my figure-8 knots stopped looking like 8s for some reason.Facility: Pretty awesome. There are so many walls for you to climb on and they're all nicely labeled with the level of difficulty. As a novice, I climbed a 5.1 with little difficulty. They even have walls for bouldering - it's harder than it looks because of the steepness of the incline, but you can get some pretty awesome photos of you on rocks! See photo taken here as an example. I make it look easy, but I let go immediately after this photo was snapped.Parking: One thing that made me frustrated about coming here was the parking situation. There's a lot outside of the facility, but most of the spots are "reserved" for the other tenants in the building, but I was unsure whether these reserved spots were still supposed to be reserved even after normal business hours. So, after deciding that I did not want to risk getting towed, I had to park on the street and climb the high wall and shrubs that separated the street from the parking lot.All in all, I loved my experience here. As a novice who's pretty scared of heights, the thrill of climbing up high and coming down is so much fun. Though you can get tired pretty quickly. I can't wait to come back.Tip: If you plan to climb for an hour and this is your first time here, you should allocate about an extra 30 minutes to the time you spend here because of the belaying test. Depending on whether you want to refresh your skills before or how busy the staff is, this process could eat up a lot of your climbing time.

Very nice place, some times is little crowded, but not to bad, staff are great and helpful, the new bouldering area looks great!!The routes are well planned and you can identify the color in the holds, they wash the holds time to time :)

Gross smell when you walk in, but that's probably normal for a climbing gym. Sloppy tapes indicating routes. Don't walk barefoot in the boy's locker room. Come to think of it, don't walk barefoot anywhere in this gym. There's a new climbing gym opening in West LA soon. It's time for Rockreation to either start shaping up or start tearing down. Listen to the customers--cheesy costume-themed nights won't cut it anymore. Tip: Give a free guest pass per month to every member to use whenever they want; limiting the guest nights to one random Friday here and there won't bring you any new members. Groupon can only keep you alive for so long. Update January 2014: I had you at 3 stars until this new set in the cave. By far, the worst set in my many years at the gym. Almost every route requires an awkward drive-by move; no skills necessary, just strength. Not very well thought out, and just sloppy and lazy altogether. Get it together people.

Started coming to Rockreation as a complete climbing novice about six months ago. Signed up for the Fight Gravity series to learn the basics and have been hooked ever since. Great facility, VERY helpful and friendly staff ready to answer my beginner's questions, and a fun place to climb!

I love this gym and i want to encourage people with bad experiences to give this place another shot. I think that the community here is really awesome. Everyone is very friendly and I can initiate conversation with most people. I spent 99% of my time in the tope roping area and this is definitely a top rope oriented gym as their bouldering area is pretty small. But if you want to boulder, there are other gyms that have more spaces for that. Not that their bouldering area isn't good, it's just a smaller section of the entire gym. I took 3 classes here. As a beginner, I feel that the classes were really necessary and I didn't mind cashing out for a few great lessons. The instructors regularly wander around the gym and you can catch them at any time to ask questions. I don't understand the complaints about odors. It's a gym...and seriously, it doesn't even smell. I feel like my college gym smelt worse. The staff here is super friendly. I don't think that people should expect the staff to try to be everyone's best friends. They do their jobs. When I ask them questions, they respond nicely. I forgot my shoes once and they didn't charge me for their rental. This demonstrates that some of the staff like to go above and beyond. I generally feel very welcoming here. The routes are well set. Of course, i'm new to this sport so what do i know but they are generally consistent. I don't feel that vary very much. 10a's all feel the same. There will occasionally be some really awkward and difficult 5.8/5.9 but i feel like i just need to work on my skills more and it's not the route's fault. People in the gym help rate the routes so they are pretty standard. However, if i do have one criticism, it would be that routes name/rating fall off all the time and staff aren't always replacing them. But really, it's not a big deal.

This is the only wall climbing place I have ever been too and I love it. Have been here twice, Rockreation has a member bring guest free night and I have had a great time and an amazing workout each time. I have done bouldering and harness climbing but where its at is traversing, I don't like heights. To top it off they have a small work out area with free weights and machines. Love that the floor is so bouncy and padded, it really helps with there whole fear factor of climbing. To top it off this place has some great views, who would have known female climbers have such great asses and for the ladies there are a lot of guys in great shape too, if you're into that. Will definitely be back, thinking of getting a membership, I hear its $60 a month. I don't own climbing shoes, but luckily you can rent them here for $4.

My kids discovered rock climbing here, and soon moved from casually interested to enthusiastic members of the Rock Warriors climbing team.  The gym has a wonderfully laid back clubhouse vibe, and even on crowded weekends with kids birthday parties, there are always plenty of great bouldering routes free to work on.  The recently remodeled changing rooms and exercise areas are top notch.

Review for the bouldering area. Crowded with a crew of boulderers who don't pause in their relentless assault of the wall. Hard to sneak in. Taping jobs are confusing, some nearly impossible to decipher if you haven't already fully mapped it in your mind. A dizzying array of colors. And only 4 crash pads for the entire are. Seems extremely sparse and the locals seem to ignore them anyway. And as a comment on the safety here, an ambulance was carting someone away when I arrived - no one seemed to take much notice and the staff member at the front desk wasn't sure how the accident occurred. Really reassuring.

I had a great experience when I signed up for a group introduction belaying class through groupon. A girl friend and I had discussed going rock climbing together many times, and were anxious to make it a new hobby. I bought us groupons for her birthday, we arrived together and I had an excellent time belaying with the group.My friend, however, claimed to have foot cramps from the shoes and was unable to do any of the exercises... idk..I came two more times to fulfill my groupon deal, each time experiencing a very friendly staff and regulars to the gym who offered to partner with me (since my friend decided to never show up again). Everyone seemed to care for my enjoyment at the gym, and I still would love to make rock climbing a regular hobby. There were young girls (10 years or younger) enthusiastically belaying solo (attached to the tethered harness) who were encouraging me to stop being such a wuss and allow myself to free-fall from the harness! They demonstrated for me how easy and safe it was.. I was still a bit of a scaredy-cat.Prices are comparable to other rock climbing gyms. Equipment all seemed to be in great working order. I went before the renovation of the bouldering area, but it was usually pretty crowded in that section. I found plenty of parking in the private lot (a few spaces for Rockcreation) or street parking (metered). The gym closes fairly early, its an ideal hobby for those who don't work normal 9-5 jobs, as you'll get the most free access without it being too crowded.

We had my son's 10th birthday party here and it was fantastic!  Von and team were great at keeping everything running smoothly.  All of the kids loved it and gained a lot of confidence as they learned the ropes (pub intended.)  There is a party room where we served snacks and dessert and the guys even helped us clean up!  Highly recommend.
Great gym for inexperienced to advanced. They even offer fitness and yoga classes. And have weights and fitness machines upstairs.

The luster of this gym has really worn off. Especially with competitive gyms now encroaching on their turf, you'd think they would step up their game. The only thing they have going for them is location; it's ideal. But other then that, they have a pretty crappy staff. Inconsistency with changing their holds on the walls (especially the bouldering area). Children running freely into the bouldering area which could end up being a lawsuit should someone fall on them. Terribly kept washrooms. Oh, and shut the damn Skrillex off. Listening to robot sex SUCKS.

I've been climbing here since Dec 2014 and I truly feel at home here. The staff here are great(shout out to Jeremy and Tracy)! The FG series nails everything you need to know to get on that rock and hopefully beyond. The gym is a bit smaller than other gyms I've been to, but Rockreation works very well with what they have:). I can't count out the efforts they are making with what limited space they have such as updating their fitness center and building more top rope walls! Their climbing routes are very interesting and challenging. When stuck with a route the staff is awesome with feedback and advice. Rockreation also offer fitness classes almost everyday of the week. I still have yet to attend one of those. But I can't wait to try them out. If you're curious or want something new you should definitely try this gym. I would love it if they opened 6am everyday because it gets crazy during the evening hours. I also hope that they get more fitness classes and start doing outdoor climbing events.

I had my 10 year old daughter's birthday celebration here. The waiver process was easy. They were ready for us when we arrived with a clean party room and 2 instructors. We got Lee and Alec (I suspect more than a few little girls are in love). These guys could not have been nicer or more patient with 10 squeely little girls. They laid down the rules, taught a few skills and managed the party's fun and safety throughout. At $25 a head and an extra $5 for goodie bags, I felt like I got a bargain. Collin is the guy that sets up events. He was clear, professional and efficient. I knew what I was getting when I walked in - no buried fees, no upselling.

I have climbed at several gyms in several states, but only the dudes at Rockreation are so interactive with us while we climb! They're a great group of people who have helped me get better at climbing and been a blast to hang out with! I'm still pretty new to climbing but they've helped me excel quickly. The climbs rotate at a good pace to get the best out of the path. Definitely going to keep coming back!

Rockreation is the only place to climb indoors on the west side of LA.  Because it's a monopoly, it suffers from the classic symptoms of a monopoly, i.e., it is undermaintained because they don't need to worry about members going elsewhere.  I only climb here because it's the only game in town, but I plan to cancel my membership when the Cliffs of Id opens in Fall 2015 (touchstoneclimbing.com/c…).I will summarize the faults with Rockreation as follows:1) The gym is outright ratty.  Poor ventilation, smelly, dirty.   I am making this comment even after the recent remodeling of the bathroom.  Not sure why they have carpeting, it's disgusting.2) Routesetters lack creativity, especially in the bouldering area.  Too many similarly styled routes - generally very crimpy and straight up.  Seldom do you find routes that are balancey, require stemming/open palm, sloper-y.  I think part of the problem is that the actual wall sucks -- doesn't really give the routesetters a lot of flexibility.  I don't like the surface of the bouldering wall but that's personal preference.  As others have stated, I find many of the routes illogically architected.  3) Route refresh rate in the gym very slow.  Often takes months to reset routes.4) Parking is terrible.5) Weight equipment is awful too - does anyone really expect to get a good work out in?   The stationary bikes are out of the 1980s.6) How can you have a rock climbing gym without a campusboard??!

I just took the fight gravity 1 series with Tracey and Christina and it was so amazing. I am addicted and will be coming back. If you want to get over a fear of heights you should try this. It's exhilarating and freeing. I feel so alive. Extremely friendly staff and a community feeling of members.

I have been climbing here for about 3 months now. I go pretty regularly (3-4x a week). And I recently graduated to climbing outdoors! real rock! Whoo!My story from rockclimbing rookie to the (somewhat) initiated intermediate climber is a great testament to the great people at Rockreation.Fight Gravity Series (1-3) classesI started out with FG1, using a Groupon. I learned how to belay, the basics of climbing and got a week of unlimited climbing. From there I opted to enroll in FG2 and 3, which gives a total of 1 month unlimited climbing, and also gives more advanced instruction and technique classes. The instructors are great. They're passionate and personable too. They teach the fundamentals, giving you a good foundation to build your climbing career. Remember to climb with your skeleton! You'll learn it ;)If you're just starting out, I highly recommend the FG series. Not only will it get you hooked, it will also accelerate your learning curve. Literally by the end of FG3 (after 2weeks climbing), I sent my first V2 bouldering problem (sent, meaning I finished it), which is not too shabby I think. The climbersThe best thing about rock climbing is that most climbers are really friendly and social. People are especially communal in the bouldering area. Friends and strangers alike love to work on problems together.In fact, a friend I made while bouldering recently took me on my first trip outdoors to climb at Echo Cliffs. It was an absolutely transcendant experience and was totally made possible by the cool people at Rockreation!The facilitiesThe gym is on the small side. Walls aren't too tall. And routes can sometimes feel limited. I boulder mostly. The problems in the boulder area are adequate. Fellow climbers have told me the bouldering problems, when compared to other gyms, tend to be reachy or strengthy. Routes get reset more regularly than other gyms I've been to which is nice. Keeps me challenged. But I climb 3-4x a week so I could see some hardcore gymgoers getting "bored." but at that point you should be getting outside anyway! Some have complained about the gym smelling bad, but to this I say, get your butt outside and climb in the fresh air!

While the staff is nice, this place is a terrible place for bouldering.  This is obviously an older gym, with short, dated walls.  However, they could go a long way in up keeping what they do have.  I climb at Touchstone, Planite granite gyms in the Bay Area and this gym can do a much better job. The walls are filthy with black tape residue, and layers of old tape everywhere.  Tape is simply put on top of old tape.  The walls and holds are disgustingly greasy.  There were a handful of newer holds, but it was limited.  There were little foot holds everywhere....why?  And they use a color system, that you have to check the wall for the rating - kinda lame.Also, setters seem just plain lazy.  About 1/2 of the boulder problems don't have a top out end.  I guess the regulars are used to this as climbers look for the end, don't see one, then top out at any place.  Touchstone is building a gym downtown.  I can't wait for all these climbers to experience a good clean gym.  Rockcreation won't be able to compete unless they clean this place up.

Sucks they're currently renovating a good portion of the gym which includes the bouldering area.  Future patrons: don't make the mistake of accidentally coming in during a kid's party--I arrived with my brother-in-law last Sunday afternoon to find the place a complete zoo.  Completely wasted workout day with obnoxious brats all over the place. On a more positive note: they have real good routes, an awesome arch for lead climbing, a great weight station that even has fixtures to work on your grip and finger strength, as well as a stair climber machine to help work out them legs.Parking can be tough, so come during the evening on a random weekday.

This gym is really nice, and it's only about 10 minutes drive from where I live, but it is so EXPENSIVE! Also if you want to belay anyone or try top roping, you would have to take their lesson, which is $45. It's probably worth it because the lesson is very extensive and it gives you a good grasp of climbing in general, and it's 2 hours long for pretty small sized groups so you deifnitely get individual attention.  You also get a week of free climbing afterwards.  HOWEVER, at Hangar 18, you learn how to belay with a GriGri for free, and their membership is only $28 if you are a student. I would say that rockreation is great for top roping as they have a lot more routes than Hangar 18.  However, their bouldering is pretty limited to a small section, and their membership is $45 a month (or maybe even more?), and I dont think there are student discounts. Top roping is definitely a lot more fun than bouldering (personally), but top rope belaying is a bit more difficult than using a GriGri, which you need to learn before you can do anything at rockcreation. They even test you before they let you start climbing.  So at least you know you're in safe hands if you do top rope?Anyway, this is probably the only climbing gym close enough for me to go to on a regular basis, and despite the cost it is a lot of fun and can be really addicting. there are probably better and bigger gyms around, but none are within driving distance. and i have close to no upper body strength so i've definitely developed more forearm muscles than i had a month ago... don't know how handy that will ever come in life... the staff is friendly and rock climbers in general are great people to be around. so give it a try! Also they had a groupon deal a while ago!

The daughter enjoyed the party overall, what I don't understand is why all the parents that come to pick up their kids a few minutes before the party ended were obliged by Von the party coordinator to sign some sort of spectator release form. These parents are just going in for a few seconds...why bother them again with yet another form??? What sort of terrible danger are they in while they watch their kids on their last climb?Also, considering the price, it would be truly nice if the staff would help you a bit with the setup, even a symbolic gesture would do.

* PERM LOST CUSTOMER & NEGATIVE WORD OF MOUTHClimbed for years... assh-le wanted money for a 5 second question - apparently other climbing yelpers have had the same experience.I've zero patience for douches.Luckily, there are many other rock gyms with better yelp/customer ratings.TIP:  $45 + 2 Hours to show you what other gyms do for FREE in 10-15 minutes

This is a super late review, but hey- better late than never. I used a online deal and took a belay rock climbing course. It was a two hour course that was exciting to my amazement. I remember showing up and being greeted by some rude obnoxious guy. I didn't give it to much thought and didn't let it bother me. It was the first time I was doing something like this so I went with it. The place had a great crowd of different ages. It turns out, only me and another girl showed up for the class. WHICH WAS AWESOME, because we practically had a private session. The two hours turned into three and a half hours of being taught and learning. It was great. I remember the instructor was an awesome guy who took his time to teach us and stayed beyond "class time." I haven't gone back since, because I don't have mates up to join. But it was okay overall.

I hate writing bad reviews. When possible, I prefer to contact managers directly about poor service. However, when I asked for contact information of a manager, I was given a scrap piece of paper with a phone number on it (no name, no e-mail), and I looked it up... he gave me the gym's number. So, Yelp review it is.First, let me preface by saying that I have been climbing for over ten years. I have done bouldering, top rope climbing, and lead climbing at gyms in San Diego (Solid Rock and Vertical Hold!). I had a monthly membership at Solid Rock in San Marcos. I then moved to Orange, tried an indoor gym, found it too difficult to climb due to financial restrictions, and so I put a hold on climbing for a few years. Now that I have moved up to LA, I was so excited to see that there was a gym near me. I hoped that I could get back into the swing of things. So, I checked out Rockreation's website. First, $26 for a day pass/gear is pretty darn expensive. I also checked out their yearly rates (since I was thinking about another membership) and found out it would be $699 for an annual membership. Wow! Still really expensive! But, this gym was the closest, so I went for it.First, we walk in and find an employee checking people in. He seems friendly, and I let him know that we are new to the gym but not to climbing. He pulls out an ATC belay device and asks if I'm familiar. I say that I've used it before, but would like a refresher. The mood changes. He pulls out a long checklist of things that he tells us we will be "tested on" to see if we can top rope climb. If we do not pass, we can only boulder... and they won't teach us or review anything with us before the test. The test includes figure eight knots, "belay on," and other basics. I let him know that I have used figure eight knots in the past, but that my last gym used grigri clips, so I would love if we could get a refresher.Well, that changes things. I am allowed to take the test, but my two friends will not be able to because they have never used figure eight knots (but have belayed and climbed extensively). He also will not show us what to do unless it takes less than "two minutes" because they're busy and short-staffed. Um, what? I have never, ever been at a gym where I was refused a belay lesson. Gyms are all about safety, but they also want people to be able to climb and pay them money! One of my friends was also pitched a belay class that cost $99 (includes month's membership and gear). I'm sorry... a belay class that costs $99 dollars? For six hours of training? Yes, it includes a month's membership. But what if I only need six minutes of quick refresher training, not SIX HOURS? And if you don't take this $99 class, you can't top rope climb. This is a blatant rip-off and poor gym service.By the way, by comparison, the local gym in SD cost $9 for a belay training. But whatever, okay, I figured I would try and practice for their test, take it, and get to climbing. I went over and practiced my knots, and asked some patrons to show me and make sure I was right. I did remember correctly, so I thought I was good to go. The only thing I didn't remember how to use was the ATC, and I figured they could at least show me that.So, my friend and I went back to the desk to begin our test. The original staff member was very busy texting on his phone (really busy, right?), so a second staff member said he would help. I explained that I had several years of climbing experience, but was a bit rusty, and so I would appreciate it if he could explain the ATC. He looked suspicious that I had ever climbed before, and he showed it to us very quickly, without explanation, as if he was giving us a cheat. I then showed him I could tie a figure eight knot as a climber, and my friend asked again if he could explain the ATC (because he had never used it). He did in about five seconds, and my friend put on the ATC correctly. The staff member then began to ask us in a patronizing tone if we could examine each other for safety issues. I pointed one out, growing frustrated--if there are any, just show us and move along!He then started to quiz me about harnesses (including kinds I was not wearing), and I decided I did not want to spend a night being patronized instead of climbing. I gave up and asked for a refund. Basically, I fail to understand how they did not have time for a five minute belay lesson, but did have time for a 10-15 minute test where the potential clients are made to feel like fools. I wanted this to be my regular place. I wanted to give them more than a $1,000/year in membership fees. But, I have never been made to feel less welcome or as incompetent as I was made to feel here. Add that to the numerous unsupervised and often dangerous climbing errors I saw around the room, and you have the many reasons why this is the worst gym I have ever been to. I guess my search continues for a new indoor rock climbing gym.

I organized a team-building session for my company at Rockreation and it was excellent.  Linda was extremely helpful and had everything ready for us.  The team that facilitated our session was patient and helpful and made it really fun.  I highly recommend this for a fun and physical team building exercise.

Really fun and great place! The staff is very cool and down-to-earth! Please take the level 1 class before u start ANYTHING!!!The boulder is INTENSE! They also have yoga. Very cool place that allows for the ultimate body strentgthening work-out.On Belay!

#Yelp #Yelp365 19 - Feet anyone? Yes, that is the overwhelming smell of this place. Our work took us here for a team building event. The staff was very friendly and we did several competitions across many different walls. They were all knew how to keep safety in mind while making the event enjoyable. Encouraging us to give a little bit more. Feet, yes, it stunk like sweaty feet on the mat and the gym equipment where people were working out, all barefoot.... a bit disgusting.

I love this gym! But you do need to be a friendly beginner or a regular climber at this spot. I've heard complaints from people who were to shy to ask for help so they had a bad time. Rockreation is more expensive than Hangar 18 but the lighting is better, the floors are softer, and the building is warmer.Families vs Single AdultsKids at Rockreation are not allowed in the bouldering area! Rockreation has great classes for kids with great teachers but they can only be on the ropes. I didn't understand why until I tried Hangar 18 in LB and spent most my time avoiding kids in the bouldering area. I'd be on a route and a kid would jump on the wall right next to me or UNDER ME. They don't understand routes so they were in the way a lot. But at Rockreation that's not a problem.Btw I've gotten a couple dates and numbers at Rockreation. It's a great place to meet cute people and make friends.Tip:Sign up for Rockreation's 3 Fighting Gravity classes for 99 bucks and you'll get a month a month's membership free and free equipment rentals. If you go climbing 3 times you've saved money and it's a great way to meet the staff and other climbers.

FIRST, the place smells...no, reeks!...like feet.  Sure, once you are there for a little while, your brain overrides your nose and you don't really smell it anymore.  But man oh man, it sure is stanky.SECOND, the customers (climbers) are all really nice and offer tips when they see you having issues.  Don't be a overly proud douche...take the tips and learn something.  Take a moment to watch some of these amazingly fit, good looking folks and absorb the skills.  If you have a question, just ask someone and you'll be surprised how helpful everyone can be.THIRD, the teachers have been very nice.  Taking the Flight Gravity class series is highly recommended as it will teach you things you will want to know asap rather than finally figuring it out after two or three months.FOURTH, the front desk people will ignore you if they are helping someone already.  Be patient and they will help you as soon as they completely finish with the person in front of you.  Then, they'll ignore the next person in line until they are done helping you.  It sucks when you are being ignored, but it's awesome when they help you until you are completely satisfied.FIFTH, this is a kid friendly gym.  If you don't like children then you'll have to go during school hours or avoid this place altogether.  Lots of hip dads bring their fearless tots here to climb and boulder.SIXTH, if you become a member, you get privileges at the other Rockreation Gyms.SEVENTH, climbing can be addictive and expensive.  It's like crack, except you remember what you did the night before. :)

I walked in and they had Gungnam Style playing throughout the gym....Awesome :)  First time climbing today with a friend, we were welcomed by the desk staff that informed us that we could do what was called bouldering, which is climbing without ropes.  You mean I can't get up on the big walls?  We decided to check it out anyway, and after being helped with our shoes were given a quick tour of the gym and how everything was set up.  Everybody in the bouldering area was so nice and helped a couple of newbies out with climbing technique.  But what we didn't expect there to be so many good looking people there.  Like really.  You didn't see any of the gross creepos at regular gyms who seem to look a little to long and sweat a little too much.  On our way out we saw a yoga class going on that was apparently free to do which seems like a great deal but we were too tired.  Climbing is hard!!!  We'll definitely be back to take the class, I WANT TO GO ON THE BIG WALL!  If you hate working out and want an alternative to going to the gym, check this place out but try to get in a class first.

When I first stepped foot into Rockreation it felt like home.  A warm fuzzy feeling like...I belong.  I was a beginner about 2 years ago and they made me feel like one of them.  It's a great group of people bursting with enthusiasm and willingness to help, assisting whenever I had a question or concern.   I currently have  a month membership after taking almost a year off. I found there have been a few changes, but good! They added automatic belays so if you don't have a climbing buddy, and don't want to Boulder, you can still Top Rope :)  I "highly" recommend this great climbing gym. They even have yoga on certain days!

The skin on my hands is so sensitive...and my arms feel like jello....Earlier today, I had my first belaying lesson at Rockcreation. I got a deal via Groupon for $35 that got me a belaying lesson (2 hours) and 2 wks of unlimited climbing. You must reserve your spot for the belaying class, which I believe happens on Saturdays (noon-2pm) and Tuesday nights from (7-9pm.) I was in a class with a group of about 10 other people. Some of us were beginners and some of us had climbing experience before. You DO NOT need any experience of climbing whatsoever to take this class. Our instructors were Dennis and Jeremy. I've read some bad reviews of the staff/instructors, but my experience was pleasant. Both the front desk and our instructors were super helpful and friendly. In the belaying class, you learn everything from putting on your harness correctly, learning how to tie a perfect "8" knot, to being a responsible belayer. From there, you and your partner switch off climbing and practice communicating the climbing lingo, such as "On belay/Belay on," "Climbing/Climb on," "Tension/Tension on, and "Lowering/Lower on." This portion of the class takes a little over an hour.The remaining time, Jeremy took us over to the bouldering section of the room. This area is basically a free climb where you climb without any support, but there are crash pads you can use. He tells you the benefits of climbing this area (great body workout/more technique minded/group activity) and demonstrates how to climb the wall...which he does so freaking effortlessly. (I tried attempting this bouldering area with my toosh on the floor, which is how you're supposed to start, and I couldn't get myself up from the floor. Me = weakling.) This area was definitely more crowded than the regular rock walls, but I liked the idea of free climbing and something more challenging. There are sections to the bouldering wall that are easier than others. All in all, I was very pleased with my purchase and hope to come back soon. Toward the end of class, Jeremy went over the other classes we can sign up for and to come back quick to take the belaying test. (I guess every climber needs to pass this test?) Side notes:-The parking lot is limited for Rockreation members. However, there's PLENTY of street parking.-With the belaying class, shoes were provided.-One thing I wish the instructors would have gone over is the whole "chalk" thing. I assumed chalk helps with a climber's grip, but we were never told anything about it. Plus, I don't think they even have a "chalk station" for climbers. I saw most people bring their own bags of chalk.-The place doesn't smell all that bad, really. Some people have said it smells like a gym, but I only smelled it when we were sitting down. Wasn't sure if that smell was from the floor or my shoes...-They have a mini gym area you're free to use.

I've had nothing but good experiences at Rockreation.  The people who work there are very nice and knowledgeable.  I took an intro to rock climbing class there recently and learned a lot about belaying and safety.  The gym is under construction currently but I'm very excited to see it when it's finished.
Staff is friendly. Not the best rock climbing gym I've been to, a bit smaller. Needs ventilation or fans.

Today was my first time at this gym and I had a fantastic time. Everyone was very nice and helpful. The employees all seemed to love their jobs and this make the experience for the patron very positive. Jeremy was my instructor and he was first rate.
