I would definately recommend Rockreation to others.

If this place wasn't far I would be hanging out here like all the time.OMG, what an awesome alternative method of a work out. I came here with my brother in law, since he wasn't smart enough to remember figure 8 tying we ended up doing just bouldering.This is obviously for people with good fitness and strong hands. And no I am not bragging about me being strong or fit (although I am), that's besides the point. You work all your body muscles to try to get as much higher as you can in the lower rocks. You definitely will need some chalk. You will feel the burn in your arms and your legs. But it's sooo good that you won't want to stop.You can practice well within 2 hours to get the trick of rock climbing. My next visit will be with the ropes and with someone who knows how to tie figure 8, just to complete my climbing experience :DThe staff is pretty friendly and helpful. You can always reserve a class to learn the basics of rock climbing. They have the shoe, chalk, rope rentals at front desk.Parking is great, either on the streets or in their lot.Have fun while rockreating.
These guys ROCK! They showed me the ROPES, and I had a great time HANGING OUT. Seriously, though, best gym in town. Colin and Von are my favorite staffers!

Coming from an avid rockreation-goer. This place would have 4 stars BUT, unfortunately they do not swap out their top-rope routes often enough. They finally switched some out this week but it must have been at least 6 months since the last time. And for a small rock gym, that just ain't cool. Other than that, love the laid back vibe and micro community of the place.

I'm new to climbing and I felt totally welcomed and safe here. The staff is very friendly with lots of their own climbing experience. I bouldered for a while before taking a belay class. The boulders were challenging (especially because my upper arm strength is pitiful) but they had enough easy routes laid for me to get comfortable. The class itself was terrific. After two hours I learned how to tie myself in ropes, check my gear and my partner's and somehow defeat gravity! Really great, can't wait to come back. They also play excellent music.

Rockreation, even though you kicked my ass I'm still a fan. Met up with some avid climber friends who let this n00b hang (haha) out with them. For $24 (and a bunch of waiver-signing) I was outfitted with a harness and rental shoes and ready to climb! We started out with the easy stuff but as soon as I hit some 5.7-rated climbs things got considerably more challenging. That's the great thing about this place; there seems to be a climb for people of all abilities (there was even a kids' group in progress). When you're taking a breather you can check out all the really good climbers and get inspired. Climbers seem to be a very mellow, supportive breed, which is great. I spent a fun and exhausting 3.5 hours here, and looking forward to my next visit. And yeah, there is a bit of a funky odor in here, but it wasn't too bad.

But sarge are we really going to crawl under barbed wire and climb ropes in combat.Dont question me son. This kind of training will save your life one day. Who knows where you'll be? Iraq. Somalia. Wall Street. Life isnt all soft cushioning and choices of easy or hard routes. What do you think it'll be like? Rockreation? Do you think there be friendly staff there when your boots hit the ground? Do you think there'll be classes for all levels when you arrive? Do you think there'll be a handy little fitness area so you can workout? Hell no! You'll be dodging bullets and praying for your momma. Now go get yourself a hot shower and get ready for your bed time story. On the double!!

I went here for one of their beginner's classes and had a great time.  The instructors were very knowledgable and were really helpful (I had never been to a place like this before and had no idea what I was doing). It was really fun and I can't wait to go back!

Glad they are here but the space is way too small - especially for Bouldering.  Way too crowded and then you have to put up with the "professional climbers" who think they own the place leaving everyone else waiting.I went twice - never again.

I was disappointed in this spot.  Having only taken an intro rock climbing class at another gym several years ago, I decided to take the FG1 (Fight Gravity 1) beginner class for $45.  It's a 2-hour session that focuses on tying yourself into the harness and on belaying, with a little bit of climbing.  You also get a one-week pass to use the facilities.  There were two teachers in a class of 8 people.  One of the teachers was very good: clear, patient, and funny.  But the other teacher did not belong in a beginner class--or maybe any class.  I heard him repeatedly say to (almost yell at) one student that her belaying was off.  He kept on saying something along the lines of: "You just did this.  What happened?  Now you keep on messing up."  Keep in mind that the student had only learned belaying about 10 minutes before the teacher made this comment.  Another student had trouble tying a knot and when that student asked the instructor for help, the instructor replied, "I've showed you how to do this a couple of times.  Now you need to figure it out yourself."   In short, this teacher in a beginner class was impatient to the point of rude. Hopefully that one instructor is not representative of Rockreation, but my first impression of Rockreation didn't encourage me to return.

i was a member here for 2 years when i lived in santa monica and didn't have a car. on the plus side: you can climb here, and climbing is super-fun.on the minus side: the walls are really small.  the routes tend to be set less well than other gyms I've visited. several members of the staff have been unpleasant to my friends and I (others are great and super nice). the gym is often very crowded.good if you're in the area, not worth making a big drive to this gym.

Hooray for indoor rockclimbing!  This was my first time rockclimbing and it was a fun experience.The facility was as warm as other reviewers mentioned, if I were a few decades older I'd be concerned that the change was finally a'comin', but a Gatorade from the vending machine cooled me down.  The majority of the facility is lined with huge rock walls, color coded with various suggested paths.  They switch up the routes from time-to-time to prevent regulars from getting bored.  If you're a newbie like me, you primarily focus on getting up the wall and not making the stupid mistake of looking down once you get to the top.  If you look down from the top, you'll probably scare the crap out of yourself and wonder, "Why the eff am I doing this?!"  A one-day pass is a great deal at $17, plus another $7 if you need to rent equipment (including a supercool harness that cannot possibly be  comfortable for men and might serve as a fabulous chastity belt).  The annual passes seem quite steep at upwards of $700, but what do I know?  They also offer classes (group and private) for those looking to get started rockclimbing.  This is a great workout!  My chest and back are more sore than they were when I tried force my boobs to grow in 5th grade ("I must increase my bust!").  People of all ages can get in on the rock fun as I saw little kids scaling the walls.  I was not about to be shown up by a 6- year old, so they provided fantastic motivation to get over myself and climb that rock.  There's also a bouldering cave with cushioned landing mats so you can practice traversing or play competitive climbing games with people far more experienced than you who scale walls like crack monkeys and smile like they've lived their lives amongst simians.  There were two members on staff at the front desk, one of whom was friendly, the other who seemed to have a permanent scowl on her face and I wouldn't be surprised if she *is* the Angry Little Asian Girl from the comic.  She knew her stuff though.Overall, it was a great experience and I look forward to going back.

What can I say about Rockreation...Staff- For the most part the staff are unfriendly.  They have a tendency to make you feel bad when you ask them for assistance.  As in, 'one of your holds just spun on me and it launched me off the wall, or the vending machine ate my cash" which is met with indolent or irritable responses.  Finally, they make you feel like they are doing you a favor if they help you.Workout Equipment- Disgusting.  This is the first climbing gym that I joined that doesn't clean their equipment.  There is nothing to wipe it down after you use it.  Basically, every time you touch any of it, you are touching the sweat of every other person who used it in the past.  Since the staff (from appearance) do nothing all day, besides answering phones, or hanging out, this should be an easy fix.Taping- Taping, and now the new color coding system is completely confusing in the bouldering area.Routes- Very inconsistent in the grading.  Some of the V2s were actually harder than the V4s.  Also, they use the same type of holds in a lot of the bouldering problems.  Climbing a route that is all side pulls is annoying.Cleanliness-   I've had to throw 2 pairs of shoes away in last 7 months of climbing here due to fungus from the gym.  Side note, I have been climbing for 16 years and this has never happened before.  The men's bathroom is a whole new level of heinous.    The smell is beyond horrible and it is consistently dirty.  I also hear that women's bathroom is just as bad.Music- This might be my personal preference, but no human gets pumped up to climb with Fleetwood Mac playing.  They have 2 stations that they switch between.  Both of which are terrible. Age Limit- There is no age limit posted in the bouldering area.  When there is a kids party, which is Rockreation's bread and butter, children constantly end up in that area which is dangerous for them and the climbers.Buddy Passes- This is the first gym I have been a part of that doesn't do this.  From a pure business standpoint, why would you not want to up your membership base?Overall, this is the worst climbing gym I have ever belonged to.   It has actually made me start disliking climbing in general, which is something that I loved my whole life thus far.  Fortunately for them, as of now, they are the only game in town, so there is no urgency to fix anything.

Came here for a team party, and was impressed with how convenient the location was, how friendly the staff was, and how much space there was to climb. Not only were there walls to climb, but there was workout equipment too. I climbed and did pullups. Great place. Would definitely return and recommend it.

I signed up for the Fight Gravity series of 3 classes and took them over 3 weeks (includes month membership and rental equipment)... and I have loved every visit so far! Jason and Steve were my instructors and they are both amazing. All the staff have been super friendly and helpful, and everyone there is really fun! So glad I found it, I'll be joining when my free month runs out, and signing up for more classes.

As an anniversary gift my boyfriend and I had our first indoor Rock Climbing lesson with Brian, we were in a small group, each taking turns to climb. Brian was great he was patient, friendly and warm. he didn't make me feel like he was watching the clock but like he truly enjoyed seeing us newbie's get excited. He would also guide you to try harder paths when he felt you were ready. I loved my experience so much I went back the next day to climb with Brian. There was a small error with my second day of climbing, the lady who swore up and down that she would put me in to climb again dropped the ball so the staff couldn't find me scheduled. I did appreciate the staff working together to fix the error so I could climb.
The staff was friendly but I had trouble figuring the place out, a little frustrating and I ended up getting bored. I tried to stay only long enough to feel like I got my monies worth.

It's like picking at a scab, you know you shouldn't but you can't help yourself. I did it, I looked down when everyone said not to and surprisingly I didn't soil myself.  What a rush.  I could feel my heart sinking to my feet.  It's like when you're on a roller coaster that's slowly creeping towards the top of the drop and the next thing you know, all the blood rushes to your face and you feel like you're going to need to be resuscitated when it stops. I am by no means an extreme sports enthusiast, but I love trying new things. Rock climbing indoors?  Yes! Rock climbing in the Swiss Alps with a rope and mountain goat?  I'll pass.Needless to say, I only stuck to the easy walls.Not to bad if you're looking for something new to try.  I suggest coming with a friend that knows what they're doing so that they can get you all hooked up and be your anchor. Best part, getting to the top! and letting yourself drop!Scary at first, but fun once you get past the initial heart attack. The prices are listed on the site, newbies will run approx. $25.That's all day in and out entrance and gear.
I took a group of students there last week from my church. The staff was really friendly and the instructors were great.Highly recommend.

I climb 3 - 4 days a week for the last 5 years. I have been to gyms all over the US, AU and the EU, and this is the worst gym I have been to. I go to this gym sometimes because it convenient. Not because it's good.This gym needs a major overhaul. They need to take better care of the equipment and facility and put some money into fixing it up.  Take some pride in this place. Set better routes. THIS GYM COULD BE SOOO MUCH BETTER.The Pros -They have cardio and work out eq and weights -They set new routes often-The Color code system for rating for bouldering is nice -Sport climbing roof is fun and sometimes well set (about 1/3 of them are good)Cons -This gym is very dirty -Walls are messy with old tape and tape residue still stuck to them (makes routes had to find and fallow  -Routes not maintained hard to fallow, hard to tell where routs begin and end  -Holds are greasy, old and beat up -Routes not well set (seems like setters don't care)- Routes are cluttered together. -Rating system totally out of wack (V5 that is really V2 and 5.8 that are 10B)- Cardio, workout eq and weights old and beat up. Also dirty -Top rope routes are really poorly set, not well maintained at all and with old holds (prob the worst part of the gym). -Overcrowded (feels unsafe with people not paying attention and walking under me while I'm bouldering -Music sucks

I may be spoiled by some other, and much larger climbing gyms, but this one didn't quite cut it for me. The staff are really nice, but I'm just not a big fan of the routes. Most of them required quite a bit of upper body strength and not a lot of technique. Perhaps I wasn't doing them correct. I'm not expert and only climb 5.10b, but I had problems with their style of routes. They also use colored rocks instead of just tape and it makes it hard to discern what is on. They have a decent bit of wall space but a large chunk of it is dedicated to lead only with no top ropes and I hardly see anyone use them. They could put ropes on a couple of the lead walls, but they don't. Not sure why, maybe an insurance reason or something. Their best attribute is their bouldering routes. Pretty decent beginning routes and they get hard pretty quick for good climbers. It was a decent place to climb for a summer, but I would get sad if it was the only gym around.

I've been to Rockreation 3 times and I've gotta say that it's pretty awesome. I was pretty impressed the first time I went with how many people there were especially since it was on a Friday night. The 3 times I've been there you start recognizing people and scoping out the regulars. This is a great place to take your first steps at any sort of climbing. Lots of fun and way safer than going outdoors somewhere like Stoney Point.

Came here to celebrate a kids birthday party. Even though the facility was bit crowded, it still managed to pull off a fun and safe event for 10 eight year olds. Staff was very patient and were capable of explaining the rules and safety tips as well. Sure Id come back and give it a go again.
Wow the classes are awesome and the staff is super cool! I'm in mega like! :D

I have to begin by saying I didn't climb here. I had every intention of doing so and got suited up and headed in to arrive as it opened on a Saturday. I had been warned that it "smelled like a gym". I was okay with a gym smelling like a gym, but there was no way to prepare me for this. The scent was so strong that the moment I walked in, I began dry-heaving. I had to explain to my husband that I couldn't stay and I ran out. I continued to convulse all the way to the car. This place is disgusting and for what it charges, I am shocked that they don't spend some money on odor maintenance. I wouldn't go here if I could stand a smell so bad, bc I think its a slap in the face to allow this when they charge as much as they do.

Well I walked in wanting to get some info and the guy at the front desk was soo uninviting and looked bored. You would think because he seemed bored that he would of wanted to show my friend and i around the facility. We just filled out a liability form and the guy at the front was pretty much like your on your own.  After we wandered around we came back to the front desk and asked a couple question, but it seemed like the guy just wanted us to leave. We asked a couple questions and it seemed as if the guy expected us to know the answers. Anyhow the place seems cool, but I hope they are aware of the lack of customer service thats at the front desk. I highly recommend you get someone who is friendly and actually intrigues someone into coming back.

The only rock gym I've ever been to so take this review with that in mind.Routes are good with frequent changes, decent size bouldering area and lots of lead climbing (maybe too much). They offer yoga and often have a lot of kids parties which take up space and routes. Also, it smells a lot lilke feet in there.... but after a few minutes you become used to it. Staff are friendly enough but don't seem super stoked to be there. I'll continue to patron but would be open to trying another gym if there were one closer to me.

They do things different from any other rock gym and expect you know their system without wanting to show you. There business model is not condusive to first timers. They deny it, but they are probably at capacity most of the time and don't need new business. Fortunately a new gym will open in March downtown - hopefully not the same owners.

Rock climbing is my new thing. Love it. I would say I am an advanced novice. Meaning if you never rock climbed before, I would look really good. To someone who climbs well, I look mediocre. This is the only one remotely close to me, the only one in LA actually so you don't have much to compare it to. Its a blend of physical and mental. So if it's the only one around, by default it should be 5 stars? Well the rock climbing itself is like a 5 star activity. It's 4 though just because a lot of other rock walls are 15 bucks a day, this one is 17. But it's LA. I can see that. But they charge you 3 bucks for chalk for nonmembers when you can buy a brick of chalk for a dollar. So it makes climbing all the time rough. And it's too far to get a membership. I live in Hollywood and this is next to Santa Monica. Its a blend of physical and mental. Prepare to create a smarter mind and body.

I love this climbing gym! The staff is so friendly - Erin, David, Colin, Von, Eric, and the climbing instructors are great and incredibly helpful (Tracy and Jeremy). They even have a great yoga class Wednesday night with Jason. Whether you are a beginning or expert everyone is very welcoming and happy to help.

I purchased the Flight Gravity series (FG 1, 2 & 3) back in 2006 but never returned for FG3. After coming across a Groupon, My friends & I started the FG series during the fall of 2010. FG1 covers the basics--safety, how to tie ropes, & how to belay. Make sure you pass your belay check before FG2, where you begin to learn the name of each of the rocks (ex. slopers, crimps, pockets) & you start to learn technique. Make sure you do a good deal of climbing before FG3. The gyms are empty on Mondays & Fridays since most of the gym patrons climb outdoors. On Wednesdays, the gym offers from yoga. Once a month, there is a Free Guest Night, where members can bring their friends. Most Saturdays you will likely encounter children's birthday parties. Despite the limited parking spaces available in the plaza, I've never had a difficult time finding a spot on La Grange. Once you enter, you will find the top-rope area and the gym area (which is limited with elliptical & biking machines as well as weights) to your left. Once you continue, you will see an area for experienced climbers followed by the ever-popular bouldering area (they change the routes regularly), equipped with plenty of mats. Once you pass the restrooms, you will reach the back of the gym, which houses the traverse walls.Despite finding slightly more competitive rates at the Southbay's Hangar 18, my friends & I signed up for membership at Rockreation because we prefer the gym and all it has to offers.

Rockreation is one of the most excellent facilities for rock climbing. Especially for a rookie climber like myself. When I first signed up for the beginner class on belay, I thought to myself, "how hard can it be, its no different than climbing a tree as a kid." Little did I know the walls at this place are enormous. They have rock climbing walls all over the place; side ways, low, on the ceiling. Yeah it was a bit intimidating watching some of these advance climbers dangle from the ceiling like in the movie "Cliff Hanger."The deals here are decent including the rentals. One of the hardest parts of the class had to be learning all the terminology. Seriously when you are holding your entire body by your finger tips there is no way in the world you remember the phrases.But what most I got out of the class was strategy part, as physical as it appears, you also use your brain to plan out the climb. I can see why everyone here is fit, after the first class you feel the burn all over. Great class, cool peeps and fantastic facility. Also made some new friends here which turned out to be as adventurous as I like to be someday. When I grow up I hope to be like the big kids dangling from the ceiling.

so thankful this place exists, its my little sanctuary. just dont expect everyone to be your friend, there are  some untamed egos . as a general rule of thumb, the harder they climb, the nicer they aint    ;)    but it's easy to find your own little corner to have a good time.
I really liked this place. It wasn't too crowded and the people are friendly. Definitely coming back

Had an OK time when I came.  I was a noob and was really excited to learn to rockclimb.  I had a friend who already knew how to belay so we didn't really need the class.  Paid $24 for a day pass that included shoes and the harness. When I was signing up, the guy at the front desk was a huge douche.  I wish I got his name because he was on a gigantic ego boost when I told him this was my first time.  He was very belittling and made me feel kind of uncomfortable.  He needs to take a class in Customer Service 101.  Won't be back because of him.  Thanks dude. The place was bigger than I expected it to be.  My friends and I had a good time bouldering. The regulars there were pretty easy going.  Have to park on the streets because the parking lot is private.Don't worry, there was a lot of street parking. I'll try the Costa Mesa one next time.

Hah! Coming from someone who didnt know a thing about rock climbing, I had a lot of fun here bouldering. Was my first time, rented some gear and had at it. They also have classes for belaying in case you want to experience more in depth climbing. I don't like really high heights so I stuck with bouldering, but that alone is really fun, i'll be coming back.

An Amazing girl brought me to this place! Pricey, but take a class and get free visits. Far better than going to a traditional gym if you just want to stay in shape. The people here are really great.Also you have to love a gym in LA that plays great music.

My 5 year old daughter has been begging to try rock climbing after seeing her uncle do it up in San Francisco.  I called the gym and they set us up with a two hour private with Cameron.  Cameron met us at the front desk and immediately engaged my daughter.  We put on our rental shoes and harnesses and went climbing.  I was not really expecting to be an active participant but Cameron nudged me along.   Not sure who had the better time, me or my daughter!!!We learned so much in two hours about routes, traversing, how best to utilize muscle groups and the technical jargon.  We will certainly come back although I could barely cook dinner that night, I was so sore!!! Thank you!

A week in LA was made that much better thanks to Rockreation.  Unlike my local climbing gym, they actually open early (Tues, Thurs, and Sat), and I loved getting some bouldering in before the work day (or before kicking off the weekend!)Staff I encountered was great, really helpful in helping you get the lay of the land, and those I saw giving instruction knew their stuff.  And the guy who was setting routes in the bouldering area knew his sh*t.I can only really speak to the bouldering area, which offered PLENTY of challenging routes, even for experienced folks, and I love the "one-armed hallway" behind the bouldering area, which I'm sure is amazing for technique building.  (I was too chicken to try it out.)The $17 day pass felt a little steep, but it was worth every single penny.  The lead climbing routes are a little bit short (this place is in a small office park, so the real estate is a bit limiting.  Oh, by the way, they have regular gym equipment, too, so you can work on muscle groups or do cardio to warm up/warm down/target/whatevs.And only park in the Rockreation spaces in the lot.  Otherwise, the parking gods will not smile upon thee.

I have to agree with James P. here. Service is weak. Really weak. They make you feel like a total interloper. Like going rock climbing is not esoteric enough that you already feel awkward when you don't know what you are doing. They won't let you use grigri belay devices (not even your own) which is quite unusual I'm told from a friend who used to compete. They're also pretty pricey ($24 for a day pass versus $16 at Hangar 18). There's zero parking (by zero I mean two spots) because the gym is in the middle of an office plaza. Overall, not the place to go.

I started climbing at Rockreation about 5 months ago with a class I got through a deal on Zozi.  The first class (fighting gravity 1) was pretty basic, just belay skills and simple climbing.  I enjoyed it enough though that I was easily talked into buying the FG2 and 3 classes as well (at a discounted rate).  The classes were great and taught a lot of technique, focusing mostly on traversing and bouldering.  Once I completed the classes, I was hooked and have been there at least one a week since.  The other climbers in the bouldering area area super friendly and always willing to help you figure out a tough route.  The staff are friendly and helpful as well.  My only complaint is that it is pretty expensive.  $17 for a day pass and at least $60 a month for membership.  I always have a hard time justifying the expense, but I keep coming back because I love climbing so much.  Hopefully I will get to climbing outdoors one of these days.

Irks me when people can have such strong opinions on a place based on HALF of a real visit. Your 20 second experience with a grumpy employee [who has to deal with you whiners every day] doesn't break this gym.PARKING: Limited reserved spots in the lot, like 6 or 8. But PLENTY of free residential spots all over. So quit QQing.STAFF: Almost all of them are pleasant, helpful, funny, and REAL climbers.REGULARS: I heart, because while climbing [bouldering] can be a real independent sport, it's awesome sharing with fellow enthusiasts [beginner or otherwise] who are willing to yell out encouragement, offer pointers, ask questions, be your friend for the day.ROUTES: Up just long enough for me to take a stab at most of the ones I want to try whilst not get incredibly bored. They'll even let you set if you've got something good in mind. Only real complaint is that sometimes [most... of the time! hehe] the ratings aren't super consistent, but that's fine.AROMA: Yes it smells. Yes it's a gym. Get over it.

The smell of feet greeting you at the door can be intoxicating but once you get used to it , it and awesome spot.investment in an air filtration system and a heater could make the place a little better.
Staff are friendly, but their bouldering and lead climbing sections are small.  It's definitely a place for top-rope climbers and newbies.

I'm compelled to write this mostly because of how great the staff is. They are friendly, accommodating, and make sure that everyone is safe and having a good time.  I've taken a couple of classes there and the instructors are skilled, knowledgable and look after everyone's needs.  My only gripe is that some of the routes are a bit non-sensical in how they're arranged and graded. But there are plenty to choose from. The renovations that are under way are going to make the place even better. The new bathrooms have lockers and are really nice.

Decent gym. Nice selection of boulder problems and auto belay is nice if climbing solo. Weight area is a bit haphazard, but looks like they're doing renovations. Only complaint is most handholds are pretty grimy. I'm used to climbing at a gym where they clean them everyone once in a while. Some were so chalky and shoe marked it was hard to tell what color they are.

Rockreation is a great workout for your core and leg muscles. I took the intro class for rock climbing & boulder climbing last night, and it was very fun and insightful. Our two instructors, Tery and Jeremy were awesome. Will definately come back for the 2nd class, which is apprerantly more based on technique and strength training. They even have yoga classes on wednesday nights! Yaayyy for fun work-outs!

The staff is great, the climbing routes are challenging, and I always enjoy my time here. It can get fairly crowded, however, and it would be awesome if they had a wall/ceiling that opened up to let some fresh air in. Regardless, this place has become rather addicting!

It would be fair to say that rock climbing is one of the best total body workouts you can get. I'm usually extremely tired after 30 minutes of climbing (I'm fairly active/in-shape, but have horrible climbing technique). This place has plenty of space for the novice or the avid climber. Unfortunately, it definitely smells like stinky socks. But that's hard to fix because the foam flooring and bolted rocks are all subject to the intense odors of the climbers, hands and bodies glistening with sweat as they attempt to make it to the next rock (sounds sexy? cuz it is).I've been to rockreation many times as a recreational climber, and as part of a corporate outing. I'd say the day pass is pretty pricey for a one time thing ($22 a day including shoe rental). Spend most of the time bouldering (climbing without a belay). Many of the people that go here are very nice and social, willing to help out others that don't have the proper technique to get to the top. But there are also some climbing snobs, that like to show off how good they are at climbing, or attempt to show off to the hot girl that is waiting to go next. That's fine and all, but the grunting noises can be ... weird.As a corporate event, this is a great place to take the company for team building exercises. They really have some great games that challenge the team both mentally and physically. AND it doesn't smell as bad when there aren't another 80 people in the gym with you.Staff is always very friendly, but the rental shoes are not.

This is the only rock climbing gym in the westside, and they sure know it.  While they've fixed the frayed top ropes and loose bolts in the walls, it still has a lot of improvement to go.  Some of my complaints, in no particular order:-About a third of the staff are rude and condescending; I've been to several gyms, having regularly rock climbed for about the last 7 years, and this place has some of the worst attitude I've experienced.  We were literally yelled at by one staff member, Steve, during the belay test he administered.  While most aren't as bad, the vibes tend to be pretty unwelcoming much of the time.-Do you like kids running underneath you unsupervised while you climb?  No?  Don't worry, the staff don't especially care.  Safety here tends to be kind of a joke, and they do little to enforce it. -How about hearing the piercing shrills of one staff member attempting to harness a circle of unruly kids? Not particularly fun/relaxing/enjoyable to climb next to.-The men's bathroom smells pretty awful, and is in pretty sorry shape.-For some reason the A/C is rarely used during hot summer days.  Another guy who used to climb here would drive from Glendale; he stopped showing up, but I happened to run into him at another gym where he now climbs, where he explained why: after driving so long to get here, and once again stepping into the place at 80dF, along with all the above problems, he finally snapped, turning around right then and quitting.-The yoga class is a joke, and there's not actually room to have the class.-Prepare to get shit for bringing in people on their guest day.  I've never gotten static before for bringing a friend in at 530pm, because apparently 6pm is when guest day starts.  In contrast, the majority of other gyms will give you a pass to use whichever day you like.Bottom line, if you live in the westside, and prioritize convenience and distance in gyms, then this is the spot. Otherwise, there is plenty better out there.

Being the only climbing gym in WLA, it's very pricey.  The routes are fine and they are changed on a somewhat regular basis (about once per month, sometimes longer). There is a good variety of routes (bouldering, top rope, and lead) with a wide range of ratings to keep everyone happy.  It's usually packed on weeknights and that can get really annoying.  Try to go during the day (mid-morning or mid-afternoon) if you can when it's much quieter.

As I walked it I smell socks, stinky socks. I think this place needs better ventilation. And when it comes to the walls since i'm not the expert to this matter some are freaking hard! Since this time i'm not using any harness and we're just bouldering all over the place.  I must say from the sport that I do which is paddling where we use more core muscles than arms, where i learned not to grip too hard and where I don't use too much forearm, wall climbing is a bit of a challenge for me... actually its HARD especially doing boulders. I did the one with the harness before its a piece of cake but this one is harder and you can be creative. Actually i like it i'm planning to buy my own gear now and get a membership from another gym cause this one is so far from my house! Will i be back? Maybe maybe not... who knows...

Ever seen popeye?michaelspornanimation.co…Yep that's me, that's what I look like after an hour bouldering.  My arms get swollen from tension, my veins come out, my legs look ripped, and my abs are a wall of stone.  Rockreation kicks my butt every time I go, if my body could take the abuse of going every day I would.  If you're looking for a new activity that will get you lean, toned, and build muscle nothing can beat climbing!

I wanted to be sure to mention how great our instructors were. Dave and Mark were both very attentive, informative, and obviously passionate about climbing. I would recommend their instruction to anyone who was interested in starting climbing.The gym is great for us because we work evenings and have free reign of the gym during the daytime. The kids' classes are well-publicized, so you can avoid them if you want. Pricing is what keeps me from giving the 5th star. You're definitely paying for the privilege of having a rock gym so close, because it falls short of competing gyms on every aspect of pricing: start up fees, higher monthly, rental fees, etc.I've definitely enjoyed my month of climbing at Rockcreation, and the only reason I'm hesitating to enroll as a member is price.

I went here on a Sunday evening as part of a team-building/development exercise and we had a blast.  The belayers were fantastic and talked us through different routes as many of us had never climbed before. There is definitely something for everyone here.  We felt totally safe and had an amazing two hours.  Thank you Rockreation!!!

I must say, I've gotten spoiled by Pipeworks up in Sacramento.  I came to RR and was expecting a lot more than what I got, especially considering the much, much higher admission fees.I wanted to keep up my climbing skills while I was down here (I'm usually only down on the weekends because of work) so I decided to pop by for a quick session with a friend.First, it's hard to drop by Rockreation if you don't know how to climb.  They'll make you sign up for a class. When they belay test you, they make you tie in and go up the wall, telling you to fall at some point.  You better trust your belayer knows what he or she is doing, baby, cause otherwise, you've just signed your life away and all the attendant will do is point at you while you lie all broken on their spring floor and laugh.I'm a small person.  My friend, L, is by no means a big person, but he's probably twice as big as me.  The top ropes are not on a pulley system, so they require a lot more muscle to belay.  Poor L got the scare of his life when he was testing and fell, cause I went flying up off my feet, into the air, and smashed into the wall, where I braced myself with my feet to catch him.  The effin attendant just said, "I knew that would happen," and went laughing off to perpetrate mayhem elseware.So now we're in and we can climb.  I understand that space is more expensive in LA, but its hard to have to pay way, way more than what I pay in Sac to climb at a gym that I feel is less impressive.  The routes are much shorter, perhaps only 25 feet, compared to the 40 I'm used too.  The bouldering area was smaller as well.I didn't realize how nice it was for Pipeworks to carefully delineate all the routes for us climbers with different colored masking tape.  Rockreation has their routes marked at the bottom with a card saying the color of the hold.  However, a lot of the holds are covered in chalk, so you spend a lot of time going, "Do you think thats my hold?  I can't tell if its black or blue or just grayish."Since there are so few indoor climbing options in LA, this place will do in a pinch, but all you climbers out there, come visit me in Sac during the week, and we'll get some true Spidey action going!******************Once again, I apologize to L for making his life flash before his eyes.

I can't compare any facility with this yet, as this was my first time rockclimbing and yay, I did it!!! All this time I thought I could lift my butt up higher than 3 feet, I was wrong!!!I was tardy, came 15minutes later than the scheduled time, but there wasn't much crowd yet, 2 staff in the front welcoming me. 1 was a friendly guy and the other one never smiled and started asking questions right away, " are you here with a group? what are you guys?". I'm like pointing out to Matt who's talking and helping someone who's about to start climbing and said, "yes, with them, we're yelpers." Wow, even after that answer, she was smirking, maybe that day wasn't her glorious day to show any smile, pshhh! Anyway, the admission is $17 for the whole day, which means, you can get lunch and come back for that same amount if you have so much strength in your body and $7 for the equipment, shoes and straps. Parking is not hard during weekend, but I could imagine weekdays. I'm glad the floor was those soft mat, which is a little bouncy so if you fell from like 8 feet, which I did, didn't hurt you at all. They also provided a slightly thicker mattress pad, but it's a little small, so everywhere you want to try new wall, you have to keep dragging it to the spot you're trying it on. This facility structure doesn't look like a rockclimbing place from the outside, cause it's joined together with like a business park complex, so it's more of those creative design space area and it's quite well hidden, unless you know the area, I don't think newcomers would notice there's rockclimbing facility inside an office building, ya know what I mean?!All in all, I'm glad I did this cause now I know I actually could do rockclimbing! For me, there's plenty of rooms to try new things, but never come later than like 12.30ish, cause by 2 when we left the place, it was much crowdier than we came.

I've been a fair number of gyms around the country, and this one falls right in the middle of the pack, which unfortunately is doing pretty good for SoCal.  I really wish this was the gym close to me, rather than the Arc in Arcadia.  Rather than a long blah review, here are the listsPros:- They have an ok amount of roped climbing and the routes are decent, though not super interesting- The walls are faux-rock and offer a good bit of friction for when you don't have a foothold.- Decent amount of bouldering space with plenty of past vertical areas and tons of marked problems- Relatively new regular exercise equipment and a fair selection of weights.- Staff was friendly and laid-back- Lots of lead-able climbsCONS:- Walls are short, though they are the exact same height as the gym I climbed at for years in NC- I've seen bigger gyms- EXPENSIVE - seriously $17 a peep, gimme a break- Parking blows, only a few private lot spaces, and then streetAll this said, I haven't been climbing enough recently and, on  a weekend where I don't got outside, I'd happily drive here rather than go to the bore-fest that is the ARC.

I love this indoor wall climbing gym. The staff are friendly and the instructors were great. You will learn essential skills how to handle the rope (belay) and of course how to climb a wall. This gym definitely will help you prefer for the outdoor one.On the downside, this gym can be so crowded that you would have to wait on your turn and parking is another issue.

The route quality is outstanding -- and it's all thanks to the current crew of setters ran by Erin (HME).  Steve (SG) is the stand-up guy who opens the gym early in the morning on Tuesdays and Thursdays.  If you come here often you'll meet motivated and fun people that all share the same passion for climbing!

The facility is pretty average here.  The top rope and sport climbing areas are fairly well maintained, but the bouldering routes are difficult to figure out.  It can be quite messy, but I was able to get the jest of it after figuring it out with some other people.  As for the atmosphere, the employees there are quite rigid so don't expect that laid back climbing attitude here when you enter the door.  I also experienced some pretentiousness from the climbers there and that is definitely not something I want to deal with when I have just given $17 for a day pass and just want to have a good time climbing.  Overall, an average climbing gym experience.  I would never get a membership here.  However, I did have a great time with my fellow yelpers :)

The ropes course was informational and helpful in terms of getting acquainted with indoor rock climbing.The actual gym itself was small and limited in terms of climbing space.  I had an extra day to use the gym through a yelp deal but never went back.Recommend the place to learn and become acquainted with indoor rock climbing but wouldn't use it as a regular gym due to limited space.
I took the beginner course and had a wonderful time. So much fun. I highly recommend Rockreation.

There's nothing like channeling your inner Neanderthal by getting absolutely shit-faced on Courvoisier and Pepsi on a Friday night, forcing you to sleep in your car in a desolate parking lot in Venice Beach, and then waking up Saturday morning, drunk, un-showered, and hungover to go rock climbing at Rockreation.This, my friends, is what I experienced this past weekend (among other things) because a friend has decided to voluntarily lock himself up in jail, er, marriage prompting a much-needed bachelor party.Lessons Learned:1. Courvoisier is a helluva drink.2. Venice Beach is a helluva city.3. Do not rock climb hungover, unshowered, and well, just plain hungover.Because when you're up 40 feet in the air with a just a piece of rope wrapped around you and you're relying on a friend down below, who also happens to be hungover, to hold onto that piece of rope, you'll be immediately praying to Jesu Cristo for some of that hyphy juice, er, red wine or whatever them Catholicos drink in a crisis.Thankfully, the folks at Rockreation realized how hungover everyone was and made sure we listened intently and learned the proper ways of rock climbing, with clear instructions and of course the signing of a waiver just in case you...uh...die.In the end, I actually enjoyed this Neanderthal act of being one with nature, albeit it's not really a rock and we were actually indoors. But I felt like I was with my ancestors. So I topped the rock climbing experience off by peeing on trees to mark my territory and clubbing a girl over the head and making her my wife.

This is the only climbing gym I've been to so I don't have much to compare it to, but Rockreation is a great no frills gym that serves its purpose. Once you get past the whiff of feet that kicks you in the face as walk in, you see slightly worn away plastic rock scattered with colorful crimpers and slopers.  There are top rope routes, lead climbing routes with an arch and a bouldering area with an overhang.  All an indoor climber could want when stuck inside on a week day.  There are also a few stationary bikes, a weight machine, a pull up area, etc. All the basics to get a climber in shape for the real rock. The gym gets pretty crowded week nights so you gotta be quick when you want to try your turn but climbers are respectful of the "one try, then step off" rule so there's no problem getting time on the rock.  If not a regular already, most everyone becomes a familiar face after a few weeks so it's easy to make friends or find a new climbing partner.  There are some really exceptional climbers there and some just starting out but altogether everyone is really nice and always willing to lend a helping hand or a word of advice...which can be good or bad depending on how you look at it. If you've never climbed a day in your life, but are a little bit curious- take the Fight Gravity 1 class for 2 hours to try out your rock climbing aptitude.  All the equipment you need is provided so all you bring is your desire to begin a new adventure and your muscles.  If you get that climbing itch like so many have, take the whole series of Fight Gravity for $99 which includes unlimited access to the gym for 30 days.  Not a bad deal.

So this was an average climbing gym in my opinion. The walls tend to be pretty crowded and it's not the biggest gym ever, which seems like sort of a rip off since it's 17$ for the day, which is expensive when you only have the arm strength to climb for two hours. Now i'm slightly biased because i'm used to the gyms in SF and Oakland, which are HUGE!!! and well, cheaper. But the price was worth it for some good times with other yelpers.The staff tends to be pretty chill if you know what you're doing. If you're new, they tend to attach to you like a barnacle. Oh well. Good times, but i'm not gettin a membership, these pockets don't go that deep!

If you live in Los Angeles and want to learn to climb or keep up your climbing skills during the rainy season, this is the place for you.  It's not the greatest gym ever, but it's got everything you need and it's in a central location.  And there aren't any other indoor gyms closeby. Pros: - There are plenty of toprope and lead routes, and they update them often.  They also have a pretty big bouldering area that sometimes seems more popular than the rest of the gym.  They offer a variety of classes (but you have to call ahead to sign up). - There's a good mix of people there - lots of super-ripped abs, plenty of beginners, always a couple scary-good kids, and sometimes a few famous people. Cons: - The walls just aren't that tall, so you can't really work on endurance.  My solution was to climb two routes in a row, and end the day with laps. - They're not very friendly.  I went there every Tuesday for two years, and each time, the guy behind the counter (often the same guy) would ask me whether I'd been there before.  That got old after about a year. - The gym-gym facilities are pretty limited.  I would have totally joined Rockreation if I could have done my regular gym workouts there too.  But there's pretty much just one bike, a bench, and some free weights. Either way, climbing is an awesome activity that challenges your mind and your body.  Rockreation's a good place to learn and practice - I highly recommend trying it out.

I hate to say this, but I've graduated out of Beach City Rocks in Hawthorne.Rockreation is a more impressive climbing gym but can get pretty crowded during week nights. Climbing fees are higher at $18/day. There's a hefty initiation fee for monthly / annual memberships.If you can get past the high cost, this gym's pretty cool. People working are helpful and knowledgeable. There are a lot of regular climbers at this gym...and a lot of group parties of guest climbers (can get annoyingly crowded).

The best indoor rock climbing gym in the area, brand new bouldering wall and the people there are really chill and friendly. Definitely a good atmosphere and sweet place for those late night climbing sessions

Love this place, its my new gym.Everyone is so nice and chill. Loads of cool people who are there to literally catch you when you fall, and cheer you alogn the way.Note: its on La Grange in the business buildign that doesn't look like a rock gym, but once you come insdie you're blown away at the cool bridge, rock walls, and boulders they've got for you to climb.

As a new climber, I took the series of two hour classes Rockreation offers (Fight Gravity 1-3), which also comes with a month of free membership and gear rental. I could not have had a better experience! The first class was the largest with about 9 people but we got plenty of instruction and individual attention, and the next two classes were just myself and two other people plus the instructor (Jason and then Steve! The instructors were really nice, knowledgeable, patient, and always ended class with, "I'm here all the time! Feel free to stop me anytime to ask questions or if you need help!" and they really meant it. It does get busy in the evenings, but my schedule lets me come during the day or early morning so it's not bother to me. I'm no pro, but the routes seem great to me, some I can concur and others I need to work at, as it should be. They also change them three days a week, so lots of new ones to work at. Over all I would HIGHLY recommend Rockreation. And no, it doesn't smell like feet. It's a gym, it doesn't smell likes roses but its not bad or bothersome.

I can't comment much on this place, because I know practically nothing about climbing. But what I got here was some friendly advice from fellow climbers (including a 12 year old who was on the team at the club). I hadn't climbed since I was in high school. Even then, it wasn't in a place with color coded hand holds and crevices. I don't know terminology, and who knows if I ever did, but this would be the type of place to learn it. And, since there are very few, I may be back here in the near future. I really enjoyed the workout it gives for the whole body. Though my fingers were easily torn by the pressure of my weight on them. I needed tape and should have thought ahead about that. I will definitely come more prepared in the future and may definitely take some of their class series. Enjoy if you go. Rates vary for time and classes and whether you get chalk, but it's all available on their site. Check out the monthly plans and it seems like buying yourself some climbing shoes is a good idea if you want to do this regularly. They also offer yoga classes etc. It's really an interesting niche.

Thanks to another yelper who pointed this out to me, the chart that shows what color course is what level is above the men's bathroom. Wow I wonder why no one pointed that out when I'm struggling on course that's WAY beyond my level!
Love the dedication of this staff at this atypical gym.  It's good fun for beginners and great when it rains or when the experienced climber lacks the time to drive out to Stoney Point or Idylllwild.

Awesome staff very helpful!! However when I called all I was told is that I needed to pass a belay test, what's a belay? I wasnt told I needed to take a belay class. But that was small compared to the fun and workout I had! I'm looking forward to taking the class and coming back for more rock climbing!

Great little gym/gem in Santa Monica area.This is a great little climbing gym.  It's not the cheapest place to spend an evening.  They have all the stuff you'd need to climb as a beginner or if you forget some gear at home.  It can get a bit crowded sometimes after work.  Make sure you bring some water to drink.  They offer classes here too so that you can learn properly.Don't half step.  Give yourself at least 3 hours here, since time will fly quite quickly.

This is a great place for rock climbing in the city and getting in a good workout after work. When i am able to complete a new level of difficulty the sense of accomplishment is amazing. I love this exercise, it is both mentally and physically challenging.

Once you get over the expected gym smell, this place is great. I'm still trying to figure out the night that's the least busiest.  I'll post back if I ever determine which night it is. On second thought, I might keep that info to myself ;)The staff and the members are all friendly, although, a male friend once told me that the "members" are friendly because most are men and I'm female. Who knows!  I love the sense of community here. Everyone tries to help everyone be a better climber or solve a problem.  If you've been wanting to try out climbing it's also a great place to take a class and try it out.  Again, the staff are friendly and knowledgeable.

This was the first place we went and researched before ultimately going elsewhere. The location itself is great and is very large. However, the reason we give it 2 stars is because for first time climbers, they try very hard to squeeze as much money out of your as possible. They charged $40 for the lesson alone including the all day pass which we didn't get the price of. Although Climbx was a lot further from Los Angeles, it was only $18 and gave us a lesson. We didn't appreciate them trying to take advantage of us and charging us for things they don't need to. Now that we got the lessons elsewhere, we might go back and review it again.

It's been years since I've gone rock climbing.  Come to think of it, the last time I may have went was in the 90s, but I might be wrong.This place is great.  Located close to the 405 and the 10 right in the middle of West LA, it's a great workout after spending the day eating too much at all the great restaurants in the area.  There's always a wall available to climb at, just make sure all your friends pass the belaying test! LOL!  They also have a workout section, boulders and places where you can hone your skills by traversing the wall.  The padding was exceptional especially when I missed this one handle resulting in me dropping a couple of feet. haha.  BYOC BTW! (Bring your own chalk, by the way).

So this is only the 4th rock gym I have been to, although I am no beginner to climbing. I have climbed in numerous states for about 18 years so I am familiar with what  a rock climber needs in a gym to stay sharp.  And for that basic reason, Rockreation gets 3 stars right out of the chute.  It has all of the basics: overhang routes, boldering caves, chin up bars, cardio bikes, VERY CLEAN locker room, etc.  It's also has a great arch system for lead climbs which almost pushed me to give it a 4th star.However, I did have some serious issues that disallowed the last two stars.  First and foremost is the price. WAY TOO MUCH. I understand tennant rates, etc., but it is still hard to justify. Even if you get a monthly membership, it is still WAY more than a traditional gym in which you are offered a much wider range of activities. Second, the routes are just not marked that well. A lot of routes are tagged at the bottom, but are then crossed out and it is like finding Waldo with the holds.  These two issues, along with the obvious height shortcomings make for a somewhat disappointing experience. I like the staff, and there is a good selection of lead routes...and like I said, I almost pushed the 4th star here. But in the end, Rockreation gets a solid 3 stars.

I had a ton of fun here bouldering with my boyfriend! He's great... I'm not so great (and a newbie).... but either way, Rockcreation doesn't intimidate - rather it makes you feel like you're just at a regular gym and everyone's doing their own thing. I was afraid to go in at first, and realized quickly that it's a safe, fun, encouraging environment with a good group of people. Drop-in's can be expensive. But try it first, if you like it, memberships aren't that expensive and if you go a lot, it makes it worth it. Definitely a unique alternative to a regular old crappy gym.

I've been a member of Rockreation for a few years now & I can not say enough nice things about their staff. So friendly! They are kind, supportive, patient & knowledgeable. Hands on & encouraging, I absolutely love these guys. I have never had a bad experience with any of them. They are also very good about constantly changing & updating their routes, so you don't get tired of climbing the same things, not to mention attentive when it comes to fixing a 'spinner' as soon as you point it out to them. Safety always comes first here, which I greatly appreciate. The gym is also home to a very friendly & supportive community, which is part of what makes it so great. The only thing keeping me from giving them a full 5 stars is the ladies locker room. It's not hideous, but could use a little work. I don't expect them to supply towels or anything, but once when I showered there after a good climb, um, some little critters crawled out of the drain to join me. They weren't exactly my ideal shower companions so I naturally reacted with the very stereotypical female shriek & jump on the nearest object off the ground technique. Not my proudest moment but what can I say, roaches creep me out man. Sorry. I will note that as soon as I notified the staff, they were on it. But I have been hesitant to shower there ever since, which does make getting a good climb in before work a little difficult, especially since they don't open until noon on Monday, Wednesday & Friday. That said, I still love this gym & their staff & will continue to be a member for as long as I'm climbing! :)

My daughter, aged 7, just attended a week of Reach Camp. She had a wonderful time! The staff was super awesome and sweet, the kids loved them. I liked that the staff seemed to have as great a time as the kids. : )The kids are never bored...there is so much to do. I was worried that my daughter was attending without having a friend there that she knew. However, she wasn't bothered by it at all, since she was having a great time. When it was time to pick her up, she never wanted to leave.  Booking the week over the phone was a bit difficult. Don't let it discourage you. I think I called about 3 times, and was put on hold for a long time each time. But when I finally talked to someone, they were really kind and helpful. I think they were busy tending to their climbers.

I've been to a few climbing gyms, and this is by far my favorite. Actually, I take that back, the Rockreations in Costa Mesa is a bit better..but I like I also like it here. Yes it's a bit musty in here, but in my opinion, I think Rockreations is better maintained than Beach City Rocks in Hawthorne. I don't boulder, but I rock-climb with a belayer. I feel that the levels marked at this gym is more accurate because the difficulties reflect the numbers. Also, the classes taught here are very helpful for beginners learning to climb. If you are in L.A, I would recommend Rockreations as the perfect place to start before you venture out to other gyms.

Of the climbing gyms I've been to, this one is a bit on the smaller side. The height of the climbs is not really all that impressive, but the bouldering area and the traversing areas were better than most other gyms that I've seen.The ropes are a bit on the old and seem to be losing some of their elasticity, and the top rope is only once over instead of the twice over I've typically seen elsewhere; so anchoring in is recommended.My first visit was on a Saturday afternoon and it was not terribly crowded (it was a bit overcast that day as well). Prices are pretty fair. I'd go here again for the convenience of its location in West LA.

If you're stuck in a gym rut, hiking rut, or a whatever rut, and want a different type of workout you should check out Rockreation. Im no rock climber but I thought that this was a pretty cool climbing gym. If they had a bigger weight room I would be tempted to get a membership. Overall rock climbing is really a unique type of workout. You use so many muscles that you typically never use at the gym. The nice thing is that you dont need a membership to come, they have some open climbs with groups and there are some other classes available. I think that classes start at about $15 (including gear rental) which is pretty reasonable.Again, I am no climber, but I think that the only thing that could be better is if there was about one more story to climb. Other than that there looked to be some pretty challenging climbing paths that you can take.

If you want to climb here and you're a newbie, sign up for their Fight Gravity 1 class with friends, which is a 2 hr class on belaying, and includes a 1 week pass.That's plenty of time to hone your belaying skills, bouldering moves, and to determine whether or not climbing's for you. You'll end up with calloused hands and a stronger upper body, along with new climbing buddies, since you usually see the same guys. They're all extremely friendly and helpful.

By far the worst gym I've ever been to..If you are a regular climber you will be really frustrated with this place. I've been climbing all over the world, inside and out, and never been to a gym as bad as this. Where do I begin...?I don't think the people behind the counter are actually climbers. Couple of them are overweight and out of shape, while the others know very little if anything about climbing and gear. (probably a big reason behind the problems here.) Their costs are outrageous, and their benefits are small. Here is a quick rundown:-$100 "startup" fee to begin a monthly membership-If you stop your membership at any time you need to pay the $100 again to restart (so you can't make this a "winter only" climbing spot..)-NOTE: You could take 2 months off, but you still have to pay a "maintenance fee" just to keep your account active.. -If you want to buy just a 1 month pass it's $100 (for ONE month)-They do NOT offer "punch cards" or other passes-They do NOT offer lead ropes for you to climb on, you have to bring your own (OMG!)-They do NOT offer guest passes (there is one specific day a month when you can bring a guest, and it usually falls on an odd day for climbing, like a Friday..)-I've been there 3 times in 3 years and they have lost my records every time, so I've had to re-take my belay test each time I've been there.-List goes on. You name it, it probably costs $100I highly suggest going down the 405 to Hangar 18 in Hawthorne where it's $99 for THREE MONTHS. You can also try "The Arc" in Arcadia which is $190 for SIX MONTHS (and they offer punch cards.) Both places have a staff which is active in climbing and are far better than the staff at Rockreation. Both places offer lead ropes for use, and both places offer cheap (i.e. usually free) belay lessons, etc.If you are serious about climbing you probably aren't rich, so I'd recommend you save your money and go somewhere else... If you want to burn money and teach people behind the counter about climbing, then Rockreation is your place.

They have an extreme waiver form that you must sign. In part you must agree to the following: "I HEREBY RELIEVE ROCKREATION FROM ANY DUTY TO PROTECT ME FROM HARM, and agree that even if Rockreation chooses to implement safety procedures such actions shall not alter the fact that Rockreation has no duty toprotect me." Wow. So, they give you a wall and straps and say Go for it! And if they help you with the straps and it is negligently strapped by them, it is not negligence because you are on your own and you should have know how to strap yourself properly. How would this business survive if this were their motto: "YOUR SAFETY is not our concern, it is YOURS."? The truth is that in a court of law a patron could and should sue them if they were negligent regardless of this waiver. The waiver is to deter those who do not know their rights. This waiver should just say that this sport involves reasonable risks that increase with your level of inexperience and non-fitness and carelessness.

It's good for what it is!  Since there are no other climbing gyms in the area, I can't complain too much.  The walls aren't as high as the other gyms I've climbed at and there's a really small workout section.

I learned how to climb here and have been a member for the past 2 years..so am a little biased...while the facilities are not totally impressive (the air circulation is not the greatest, and there isn't enough work out equipment), the bouldering area is solid, the routes are challenging, and most of all the community is friendly and helpful for folks of all levelsIf you are interested in learning, I recommend doing the 3 class package (comes with a free month of rentals/ admission - around $90). If you're more advanced, I recommend going during the morning on Tues/ Thurs (open at 6am) - there is a small group of regulars that go and it is not crowded whatsoever.

While the facilities themselves are quite functional, rockreation is smelly, rude and generally unpleasant.  I would rather make the 35 minute drive down to Hangar 18 in Manhattan beach, than the 5-10 minute commute to rockreation.  The staff is condescending and does not seem to care at all.  Not to mention this attitude seems contagious.  The atmosphere there is one I would recommend to someone I don't like.  To top it off they are pricey too.

I climbed here when I first moved to LA and had a year membership for a while there - but haven't been back since.  I've climbed in gyms in NC, AR, MA (3 different ones), and UT - Rockreation was easily my least favorite of them.  The gym is expensive; a number of reviewers have said that so I'm not going to belabor the point.  And some of the staff are a bit on the evil side.  I used to warn students (I've taught a few hundred people how to climb) not to be intimidated by them as they got tested on their belay skills.  If they can intimidate someone who can belay in their sleep, they can make a beginner wet themselves.  I did take a good lead climbing class with them, and i wish I could remember that staff member's name so i could compliment them now as I've lead (and taught lead climbing) for years now and never been involved in an accident.  Janet, Tavis, and Phil (if any of them still work there) are all chill people - so if you get them to help you out, congrats.  One of my bigger complaints (possibly rectified by now) concerns their ropes...  The top ropes were of pretty poor quality - stiff and not very easy to use.  And I hated the fact that you had to use their ropes to lead with.  I have no idea how many falls have been taken on them and trusting them seems foolish.  There are no staff counting how many falls are taken I bet you that they aren't retired as often as they should be.  My favorite gym (Rockhaus in Logan, Utah) required you to have, use, and maintain your own rope after you passed their lead test.  Their reasoning is probably the same as Rockreations - liability.  At any rate, now that I've moved to Culver City I may have to see what gyms are nearby.  Rockreation is right up the street, but the quality of service isn't worth the price...

This place is really great.Considering the small amount of indoor climbing there is, this place really gets the job done.  TONS of really good bouldering, and top roping.The prices can be a little steep, but that sort of comes with the sport.  Staff is friendly, laid back, and knowledgable.If you don't know anything, lots of people there are willing to help you learn, but don't try to fudge your way thru like you know what you're doing.  Everyone in that gym can smell BS from a mile away.Good music, good people, and good times!  Where do i get the annual membership?
This gym is not worth the money.  It's way overpriced, there is limited parking, and worst of all the staff is rude.  Also, the routes are poorly set.

I went to rockreation for the first time with a friend a few days ago.  I got there early, and was unimpressed at first.  The bouldering is not great and it was way too crowded.  When my friend showed up, however, we had a great time traversing and TRing.  Cons: Bouldering not great.  Not a great place to go solo.Pros: Fun cracks to practice on, Decent top ropes, pumpy traverses and a really good sport/lead area.Bottom Line: Go with a friend and you'll have a good time.

I think I would give this a 3.5 if I could, but as it is, it leans a little closer to 4.This is a fairly decent gym, and probably the best (only) one you'll find within a reasonable distance from the West LA area. Some of the staff seem to be a little despondent sometimes, but who can blame them? Standing behind a counter for hours on end and telling people to not be stupid and endanger their own lives can get pretty tiring I imagine. Otherwise, I've always found the staff to be cheery and helpful. Compared to most gyms I've been to, this place is pretty expensive. 17 for a day pass, not including gear rentals. ouch. Other notes: the boulder problems are rotated fairly regularly so you shouldn't ever get too bored of the place; lead/TR walls are a little short which is a bummer. All in all, there are some fine climbs in here, although I think there's a slight tendency for the problems to be sandbagged.
This place is awesome. The people are friendly and the routes change every month. Parking isn't as bad as it seems, as there is a ton of street parking.

Wow! This place is awesome, I brought my wife here really as kind of a goof, because we're always saying we need to get out of the house and do something. Well this is totally something. Holy s&%#, what an experience!  All the instructors are experienced climbers and know every aspect of climbing and how to let you do it confidently and safely. Big emphasis on safety, because if you don't pay attention ... well, lets just say that was part of the thrill.  Fortunately I didn't have any problems with the staffs attentiveness at the front desk, and the forms are very detailed as far as releasing Rockreation from liability, but they have to, people will sue a place for anything. If you go skydiving it's even worse, they just about say we can murder you and there's nothing you can do about it, so this wasn't bad at all. It's all just CYA.  Anyway, lots of fun, I got a great Groupon deal, $19 each, which included a one week membership. Check it out if you're looking for something cool and different. This would be a great first date thing to do!  Just don't scream like a girl when you get to the top.

I don't like Rockreation's routes as well as Beach City Rocks': there aren't  enough chances to learn to lead, and they don't have those cool auto-belay devices that allow one to climb alone. Rockreation's color-coded route-indicating holds are quite novel, but they're arbitrary too. Routes are run-out and hard to follow. It must be a drag to work here and to have to change the routes all the time; tape is less permanent, of course, but easier to manipulate. As is, might I add, the gym's rating system. I can tell that several people determined, without collaboration, what's a 5.6 or a 5.8. However, the employees' attitudes at Rockreation are far and away superior to those at Beach City Rocks. I particularly liked the (gorgeous, sweet, shaved-headed) man who tested my abilities as a climber, in order that I might belay 500 fellow Yelpers :). Kidding, kidding.  Also if you like to boulder (I don't), this is your gym.I'll likely be back, primarily due to its cheaper gym membership options and its proximity to UCLA.
at last a west side gym with no attitude. fun vibe. attentive staff. kids love it. I'm going back

i've had this itch recently. i've been climbing on my couch a little too much. jumping up stairs, climbing over fences. so i decided it was time to go to rockreation. i've only climbed a manmade wall ONCE, and it was on a cruise. go figure. and the next day, i was unable to open the top of a water bottle. yep. a water bottle, my fellow yelpers. you work out muscles you literally never knew you had. i'm slightly banged up right now. few scrapes on hands, bruises on knees, but overall A-OK. : ) except for the fact that my fingertips are PETRIFIED. piano practice was quite painful today post climbing. you get 22 dollars. (17 for full day pass, other 5 for borrowing shoes). there are cubby holes, but i suggest you keep valuables close to you, since there's always a chance some a hole feels an itch to grab something other then a rock wall. the person in front was very helpful. and i even got a couple of tips from an expert climber there! when you walk in, go left, all the way to the end, and you'll see some simple walls you can traverse and train on! there are heavy mats you can put under yourself in case you take a spill, and yes, you WILL take a spill. everything is color coded, go for the pink tapes, cuz those are the easiest. i went with Ben G. which means he put me to shame with this monkey-climbing ways. it's ok. i set mini goals for myself, and i did it towards the end, while simultaneously popping out SOMETHING in my left shoulder. gah. reading through past reviews, i did notice some snarky, holier then thou rock climbers there. but fuck them, i'm not there to impress them. i stuck by the kick ass nice climbers. : ) this is a super super fun way to stay in shape, AND hanging out with buddies. try to go for at least 3-4 hours. take mini breaks in between, and you're golden. see you all at the top!

Welcome to the cult of rock climbers. As a member of this cult you will join a new community of friends from all walk of life. Soon after learning the basic techniques, you will make this place your second home. You'll hang out at the gym after hours, socializing, climbing, and planning weekend outdoor climbing trips. Your wardrobe's "climbing gear" section will grow exponentially until soon you will dress like a mountaineer always. Your hands will always be dry from the chalk and your nails will barely survive past your fingertips. You'll start to see the climbing trails in your sleep, and you'll spend precious work time daydreaming about the next weekend trip or about the challenging technique of a puzzling climb. Soon, your sense of humor will incorporate dorky climbing metaphors and double entendres. You'll start camping in random places and random people's backyards, and you're gonna want all your friends and family and coworkers and neighbors to become rock climbers just like you!Whoa, I'm just here to climb the walls. [2 hours later]Um excuse me, where do I sign up? I'm hooked. :)

A little difficult to find!!!  It's tucked into an office center with a lack of signage.  Parking looks dubious but you can actually park in any of their assigned spots.  I think this place is more geared towards top rope and lead climbing, but the bouldering wasn't bad.  I do prefer Hangar 18 for bouldering but this place had a lot more space.  Very cool staff.

I took the first of fight gravity classes yesterday and was impressed. The instructors were thorough and gave clear instructions. Most notable was our instructor Jeremy who spoke with passion and gave sincere advice. What really made him stand out was after the class was over he continued to answer questions and give sound advice. I highly recommend spending the money on the class.

4 stars for facility pricing and instructors2 stars for the front desk guy who wouldn't get off the phone for a sec to explain anything to me about the form he was making me sign to enter even tho I was not climbing... Apparently I need to give my blood type, my first born and every piece of info needed to steal my identity just to watch my niece and friends climb for her 11 th bday.  coming from a customer service background, that really bothered me.  otherwise, I loved everything about this place. This is a big climbing facility with friendly knowledgeble staff.  $25 for two hours.

Good climbing gym, has all your standard stuff. Some workout equipment, a decent-size locker room/bathrooms, everything is clean and adequately maintained. The cost is rather high, $17 for just a day pass, and the membership costs only supports hard-core climbers.

The photos were sort of misleading. The gym's highest routes are barely 2 floorrs. I didn't bother with the top rope and stuck to bouldering. The routes were impossible to follow, the ratings were tacked to a cork board in the form of a piece of cardboard with the different colored tapes and their relative ratings. I saw a number of people trying to figure out where the bouldering routes went or to which route a given peg belonged. The walls look like they were slapped together in someone's garage and the holds haven't been cleaned, oh ever. This place reminds me of a tiny version of Mission Cliffs in SF.

You're only a few feet away from the ground, clutching a rock with your fingers and you look down and fear/panic take a hold of you. Rock climbing is for those who thrive on adrenaline, and want to get in fantastic shape. Granted, I've only gone rock climbing a few times, but I liked this place. I came in, thinking I had no fear of heights, but rock climbing is scary if you let your mind create worst case scenarios. Even so, I found someone who was very encouraging to help with belaying and learning how to climb. The staff  explained some safety tips which helps with the fear. I like belaying because of the psychological feeling of safety. Bring your own shoes and chalk, if possible. You could always try one some shoes at REI to find your fit and then buy that type online to save money.
